【13】Chief Complaint:
【14】Increased lumbar wound drainage, s/p lumbar fusion and lumbar 
【15】wound washout for MSSA infection
【16】 
【17】Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
【18】Lumbar wound washout with removal and replacement of surgical 
【19】hardware on ___.

【22】History of Present Illness:
【23】Mr. ___ is a pleasant ___ year old gentleman who 
【24】presented to the ER at ___ for evaluation of drainage from
【25】his spine wound. He underwent anterior and posterior
【26】decompresison and fusion with instrumentation from T11-L3 in
【27】___. His post-operative course from this most recent
【28】procedure was unfortunately complicated by a wound infection and
【29】was taken back to the operating room on ___ for irrigation
【30】and debridement of the thoracolumbar spine wound. At that time,
【31】infectious disease was consulted and the patient was started on
【32】IV cefazolin and rifampin. Wound cultures obtained at that time
【33】grew MSSA and CONS spp. Patient was discharged from the hospital
【34】on ___ to a rehab facility where was recovering until
【35】approximately one week prior. He reports that he was progressing
【36】well until this morning when after waking up, he noted
【37】signfiicant drainage from the mid and distal portions of his
【38】spine surgical wound. 
【39】He denies any fevers,
【40】chills, or constitutional symptoms. He denies any new weakness,
【41】numbness, or paresthesias in his lower extremities.
【42】
【43】

【45】HTN

【54】Surgical wound present extending from the lower thoracic spine
【55】down to the lower lumbar spine. staples are intact. dehiscence 
【56】in the central portion of the wound. There is no
【57】fluctuance or surruonding erythema. 
【58】
【59】Motor
【60】     C5     C6     C7     C8     T1
【61】R     5      5      5      5      5
【62】L     5      5      5      5      5
【63】sensation intact in above dermatomes
【64】
【65】

【67】___ 11:30AM   WBC-7.2 RBC-3.58*# HGB-9.3*# HCT-31.8*# 
【68】MCV-89 MCH-26.0* MCHC-29.2* RDW-15.4
【69】 
【70】Brief Hospital Course:
【71】Mr. ___ was readmitted to ___ with increased wound drainage 
【72】from his lumbar incision on ___. He was made NPO. He was 
【73】taken to the OR on ___. He underwent a lumbar wound washout 
【74】with replacement of his surgical hardware and re-closure. HE was 
【75】placed back on IV antibiotics and infectious diseases team was 
【76】consulted for recommendations. Intra-operatively the patient was 
【77】found to have gross purulent drainage from the inferior aspect 
【78】of the wound. There was abundant purulent material below the 
【79】fascia. Cultures were sent. All hardware was removed, with new 
【80】hardware put in
【81】place. A wound vac was placed. He was started on vancomycin, and
【82】continued on rifampin 300mg PO Q12H.
【83】
【84】Initially, postop pain was controlled with a PCA.  Diet was 
【85】advanced as tolerated.  The patient was transitioned to oral 
【86】pain medication when tolerating PO diet.  Foley was removed on 
【87】POD#2 and the patient was voiding well. Post-operative labs were 
【88】grossly stable. A wound Vac and A hemovac drain that was placed 
【89】at the time of surgery was also removed on POD#2.  Physical 
【90】therapy was consulted for mobilization OOB to ambulate. A TLSO 
【91】brace was fitted for the patient. Hospital course was otherwise 
【92】unremarkable.  On the day of discharge the patient was afebrile 
【93】with stable vital signs, comfortable on oral pain control and 
【94】tolerating a regular diet.
【95】
【96】Final infectious diseases recommendations switched the patient 
【97】back to IV ancef 2gm Q8h with rifampin 300mg BID. 
【98】Recommendations were given for labs and follow up.
【99】
【100】

【102】At home:
【103】Miralax prn
【104】Neurotin 200 mg Q8 hrs
【105】Ferrous sulfate 325 m PO QD
【106】Hydromorphone 4 mg PO Q 3 hrs prn pain
【107】Diazepam ___ m PO Q 6 hrs prn spasms
【108】IV cefazolin per OPAT
【109】Rifampin 300mg PO Q12H 
【110】
【111】

【113】1. Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q8H:PRN pain 
【114】2. Diazepam 5 mg PO Q6H:PRN muscle spasm 
【115】RX *diazepam [Valium] 5 mg 1 tab by mouth every six (6) hours 
【116】Disp #*90 Tablet Refills:*0
【117】3. Ferrous Sulfate 325 mg PO DAILY 
【118】4. Gabapentin 200 mg PO TID

【121】Disp #*90 Tablet Refills:*0
【122】6. Miconazole Powder 2% 1 Appl TP QID:PRN fugal rash 
【123】7. Morphine SR (MS ___ 15 mg PO Q8H 
【124】RX *morphine [MS ___ 15 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every eight 
【125】(8) hours Disp #*90 Tablet Refills:*0
【126】8. Polyethylene Glycol 17 g PO DAILY:PRN constipation 
【127】9. Rifampin 300 mg PO Q12H 
【128】RX *rifampin 300 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth every twelve (12) 
【129】hours Disp #*60 Capsule Refills:*0
【130】10. CefazoLIN 2 g IV Q8H 
【131】RX *cefazolin in dextrose (iso-os) 2 gram/50 mL 1 bag IV every 
【132】eight (8) hours Disp #*60 Intravenous Bag Refills:*0

【134】

【136】Extended Care
【137】 
【138】Facility:
【139】___
【140】

【142】Lumbar wound infection
【143】
【144】

【146】Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
【147】Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
【148】Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
【149】
【150】 
【151】Discharge Instructions:
【152】LAB MONITORING RECOMMENDATIONS: NOTE: For lab work to be drawn
【153】after discharge, a specific standing order for Outpatient Lab
【154】Work is required to be placed in the Discharge Worksheet -
【155】Post-Discharge Orders. Please place an order for Outpatient Labs
【156】based on the MEDICATION SPECIFIC GUIDELINE listed below:
【157】
【158】ALL LAB RESULTS SHOULD BE SENT TO:
【159】ATTN: ___ CLINIC - FAX: ___
【160】
【161】WEEKLY LABS: CBC with differential, BUN, Cr, ESR, CRP, ALT, AST,
【162】AlkPhos, Tbili 
【163】
【164】FOLLOW UP APPOINTMENTS: f/u with ID in ___ weeks
【165】
【166】All questions regarding outpatient parenteral antibiotics after
【167】discharge should be directed to the ___ R.N.s at
【168】___ or to the on-call ID fellow when the clinic is
【169】closed. 
【170】
【171】PLEASE NOTIFY THE ID SERVICE OF ANY QUESTIONS REGARDING THESE
【172】RECOMMENDATIONS OR WITH ANY MEDICATION CHANGES THAT OCCUR AFTER
【173】THE DATE/TIME OF THIS OPAT INTAKE NOTE.
【174】
【175】ACTIVITY: DO NOT lift anything greater than 10 lbs for 2 weeks. 
【176】 
【177】 
【178】___ times a day you should go for a walk for ___ minutes as 
【179】part of your recovery. You can walk as much as you can tolerate. 
【180】
【181】 
【182】You will be more comfortable if you do not sit or stand more 
【183】than ~45 minutes without changing positions.
【184】 
【185】 
【186】 
【187】BRACE: You have been given a brace. This brace should be worn 
【188】for comfort when you are walking. You may take it off when 
【189】sitting in a chair or while lying in bed.
【190】 
【191】 
【192】WOUND: Remove the external dressing in 2 days. If your incision 
【193】is draining, cover it with a new dry sterile dressing. If it is 
【194】dry then you may leave the incision open to air. Once the 
【195】incision is completely dry, (usually ___ days after the 
【196】operation) you may shower. Do not soak the incision in a bath or 
【197】pool until fully healed. If the incision starts draining at any 
【198】time after surgery, cover it with a sterile dressing. Please 
【199】call the office. 
【200】
【201】Please call the office if you have a fever>101.5 degrees 
【202】Fahrenheit and/or drainage from your wound.
【203】 
【204】 
【205】MEDICATIONS: You should resume taking your normal home 
【206】medications. Refrain from NSAIDs immediately post operatively.
【207】 
【208】 
【209】You have also been given Additional Medications to control your 
【210】post-operative pain. Please allow our office 72 hours for refill 
【211】of narcotic prescriptions. Please plan ahead. You can either 
【212】have them mailed to your home or pick them up at ___ 
【213】___, ___. We are not able 
【214】to call or fax narcotic prescriptions to your pharmacy. In 
【215】addition, per practice policy, we only prescribe pain 
【216】medications for 90 days from the date of surgery.
【217】 
【218】
【219】 
【220】Followup Instructions:
【221】___

【110】Brief Hospital Course:
【111】Mr. ___ is a ___ male with a history of urothelial 
【112】carcinoma of the bladder with prostatic urethral involvement who 
【113】presented to the FICU from the PACU after undergoing radical 
【114】cystectomy with ileal conduit creation and umbilical 
【115】herniorraphy due to inability to wean pressors. His FICU 
【116】concerns were:
【117】
【118】# Hypotension:
【119】Possibly in setting of epidural. Differential includes 
【120】hypotension in the setting of hypovolemia ___ blood loss (had 
【121】significant drop in Hgb, will recheck CBC). Originally was 
【122】placed on phenylephrine. Urology remains convinced that this is 
【123】in setting of epidural even though the anesthetic component was 
【124】quite minimal. As such, coordination with the pain team allowed 
【125】for bupivacaine potency to be reduced to half on ___, and then 
【126】subsequently discontinued on ___ given no worsening of pain. He 
【127】was placed on a dilaudid PCA as a replacement for pain control. 
【128】He was also continued on maintenance IVF at a rate of 150mL/hr 
【129】on ___, transitioned to 100mL/hr on ___. Hb decreased to 9.5 as 
【130】of ___, however, this is likely secondary to dilution effects.
【131】
【132】# Post-operative pain management: well controlled
【133】His post-operative epidural and then transition to PCA was 
【134】managed as described above. He was also placed on acetaminophen 
【135】1g PO q6h PRN as adjunct. This was combined with Zofran PRN for 
【136】nausea, and a Naloxone drip PRN for itching.
【137】
【138】CHRONIC ISSUES  
【139】
【140】# VTE Prophylaxis: 
【141】- TID SQ heparin dosing or enoxaparin 40mg SC daily is 
【142】acceptable
【143】for thromboembolism prophylaxis while catheter in place.  If
【144】using enoxaparin, please hold dose the morning of planned
【145】catheter removal.
【146】- Venodyne boots while sedentary
【147】
【148】# HYPERCHOLESTEROLEMIA 
【149】# HYPERTENSION 
【150】# SEASONAL RHINITIS 
【151】# MILD CAROTID STENOSIS
【152】# AORTIC STENOSIS S/P AVR ___
【153】
【154】Mr. ___ transferred to the general surgical floor and to the 
【155】urology service on POD2. Mr. ___ Patient received 
【156】___ intravenous antibiotic prophylaxis and deep vein 
【157】thrombosis prophylaxis with subcutaneous heparin. With exception 
【158】to the FICU course for hypotension, his hospital course was 
【159】essentially unremarkable. With the eventual passage of flatus, 
【160】diet was gradually advanced and the
【161】patient was transitioned from IV pain medication to oral pain 
【162】medications. The ostomy nurse saw the patient for ostomy 
【163】teaching. At the time of discharge the wound was healing well 
【164】with no evidence of erythema, swelling, or purulent drainage. 
【165】His drain was removed and the ostomy was perfused and patent and 
【166】the ureteral stents were visible. Post-operative follow up 
【167】appointments were arranged/discussed and the patient was 
【168】discharged home with visiting nurse services to further assist 
【169】the transition to home with ostomy.  
【170】
【171】 
【172】Medications on Admission:
【173】The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
【174】1. Valsartan 40 mg PO DAILY 
【175】2. Atorvastatin 40 mg PO QPM 
【176】3. Aspirin 162 mg PO DAILY 
【177】4. clindamycin phosphate 1 % topical ASDIR 
【178】5. econazole 1 % topical DAILY:PRN

【180】

【184】3.  Nitrofurantoin Monohyd (MacroBID) 100 mg PO DAILY 
【185】RX *nitrofurantoin monohyd/m-cryst [Macrobid] 100 mg one 
【186】capsule(s) by mouth DAILY Disp #*14 Capsule Refills:*0 
【187】4.  Senna 8.6 mg PO BID  
【188】5.  Atorvastatin 40 mg PO QPM  
【189】6.  clindamycin phosphate 1 % topical ASDIR  
【190】7.  econazole 1 % topical DAILY:PRN  
【191】8.  Valsartan 40 mg PO DAILY  
【192】9. HELD- Aspirin 162 mg PO DAILY  This medication was held. Do

【215】Discharge Instructions:
【216】Please also refer to the instructions provided to you by the 
【217】Ostomy nurse specialist that details the required care and 
【218】management of your Urostomy
【219】
【220】-You will be sent home with Visiting Nurse ___ 
【221】services to facilitate your transition to home, care of your 
【222】urostomy, etc.
【223】
【224】-Resume your pre-admission/home medications except as noted. 
【225】Always call to inform, review and discuss any medication changes 
【226】and your post-operative course with your primary care doctor
【227】
【228】-___ reduce the strain/pressure on your abdomen and incision 
【229】sites; remember to log roll onto your side and then use your 
【230】hands to push yourself upright while taking advantage of the 
【231】momentum of putting your legs/feet to the ground.
【232】
【233】--There may be bandage strips called steristrips which have 
【234】been applied to reinforce wound closure. Allow these bandage 
【235】strips to fall off on their own over time but PLEASE REMOVE ANY 
【236】REMAINING GAUZE DRESSINGS WITHIN 2 DAYS OF DISCHARGE. You may 
【237】get the steristrips wet.
【238】
【239】For pain control, try TYLENOL (acetaminophen) FIRST, and then 
【240】take the narcotic pain medication as prescribed if additional 
【241】pain relief is needed.
【242】
【243】-Do not eat constipating foods for ___ weeks, drink plenty of 
【244】fluids to keep hydrated
【245】
【246】-No vigorous physical activity or sports for 4 weeks or until 
【247】otherwise advised. Light household chores/activity and leisurely 
【248】walking/activity is OK and should be continued. Do NOT be a 
【249】couch potato
【250】
【251】-Tylenol should be your first-line pain medication. A narcotic 
【252】pain medication has been prescribed for breakthrough pain ___.
【253】
【254】-Max daily Tylenol (acetaminophen) dose is THREE to FOUR grams 
【255】from ALL sources
【256】
【257】 AVOID lifting/pushing/pulling items heavier than 10 pounds (or 
【258】3 kilos; about a gallon of milk) or participate in high 
【259】intensity physical activity (which includes intercourse) until 
【260】you are cleared by your Urologist in follow-up.
【261】
【262】-No DRIVING for THREE WEEKS or until you are cleared by your 
【263】Urologist
【264】
【265】-You may shower normally but do NOT immerse your incisions or 
【266】bathe
【267】
【268】-Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics and do not 
【269】operate dangerous machinery
【270】
【271】-You may be given prescriptions for a stool softener and/or a 
【272】gentle laxative. These are over-the-counter medications that may 
【273】be health care spending account reimbursable. 
【274】
【275】-Colace (docusate sodium) may have been prescribed to avoid 
【276】post-surgical constipation or constipation related to use of 
【277】narcotic pain medications. Discontinue if loose stool or 
【278】diarrhea develops. Colace is a stool-softener, NOT a laxative.
【279】
【280】-Senokot (or any gentle laxative) may have been prescribed to 
【281】further minimize your risk of constipation. 
【282】
【283】-If you have fevers > 101.5 F, vomiting, or increased redness, 
【284】swelling, or discharge from your incision, call your doctor or 
【285】go to the nearest emergency room.

【176】peripheral IV.  
【177】
【178】 
【179】Brief Hospital Course:
【180】___ yo male with recent small bowel resection, presented with 
【181】FTT, admitted to ICU for hypotension, and found to have severe 
【182】electrolyte abnormalities
【183】
【184】# HYPOTENSION - The patient was noted to be hypotensive in the 
【185】emergency department which was felt to be secondary to 
【186】significant intravascular depleating in the setting of poor PO 
【187】intake and continued lasix use.  Infectious work-up including 
【188】chest xray, UA was negative. Aside from diarrhea there was no 
【189】sign of infection. Hypotension resolved with fluids prior to 
【190】arrival to the MICU. Stress dose steriods were initally given 
【191】for concern for adrenal insufficieny however labs were not felt 
【192】to be consistent with this picture and he was put back on his 
【193】home prednisone on HD His home antihypertensives were held given 
【194】hypotension. Blood pressures remained stable throughout his MICU 
【195】stay. Once patient was transitioned to the floor we resumed 
【196】metoprolol and lasix, and attempted to resume lisinopril however 
【197】this resulted in orthostatic hypotension and was discontinued. 
【198】
【199】# Failure to Thrive - Admission Albumin 2.3 and patient endorses 
【200】almost no appetite, with minimal solid food intake for the last 
【201】___ weeks post small bowel resection (note this is his ___ small 
【202】bowel resection, first was in ___. Without abdominal pain, 
【203】without nausea or emesis and no obstruction on AXR.  Overall, 
【204】etiology most consistent with Recent and distant small bowel 
【205】resections leading to "Short Bowel Syndrome" with overall 
【206】malabsorption, diarrhea, electrolyte disturbances, and other 
【207】vitamin/mineral deficiencies. Nutrition was consulted a 
【208】performed a calorie count which showed pt consuming 1600 
【209】calories by discharge. Recommended continued ensure suppliments. 
【210】No need for TPN at this time. He was started on mirtazepine for 
【211】appetite stimulation and sleep. 
【212】
【213】# Diarrhea, history of Carcinoid- As above concerning for short 
【214】gut syndrome given numerous surgeries. Known carcinoid tumor 
【215】could also be contributing. Cdiff was negative. Pt started on 
【216】psyllium wafers and loperamide with significant improvement in 
【217】stools. At discharge pt with 2 formed stools per day.  
【218】 
【219】Oncology was consulted and recommended outpatient follow-up. Pt 
【220】seen by primary oncologist Dr. ___ prior to discharge 
【221】who recommended 24hr urine collection, serum serotonin, quant 
【222】IgG and chromogrannin levels which were all check prior to 
【223】discharge. Also recommended octreotide study which will need to 
【224】be arranged as an outpatient.
【225】
【226】# Normocytic Anemia - Admission Hct 28, discharge on ___ Hct 
【227】24, Since ___ Hct in the low ___. B12 on ___ normal. Likely 
【228】explains malaise/fatigue. B12 normal from ___. Folate normal 
【229】this admission. Iron was low. Pt started on oral iron 
【230】suppliments during admission. However concern that he will not 
【231】absorb well given partial ileum resection. Should have Hct and 
【232】iron repeated as out patient and consider IV iron if not 
【233】improved.
【234】
【235】#Peripheral Edema: Pt w/significant lower and upper extremity 
【236】edema. These improved with compression stockings and home po 
【237】lasix. LUE remained edematous as other extremities improved. 
【238】___ of LUE did not show DVT.
【239】
【240】#Insomnia: pt started on mirtazapine at night for sleep and 
【241】appetite with improvement in both.
【242】
【243】#GERD: Prior to admission PPI stopped. Pt unsure why, but likely 
【244】___ low Mg given electrolyte abnormalities on admission. Sx 
【245】improved with ranitidine and Tums.
【246】
【247】-------
【248】Chronic
【249】-------
【250】# CAD with MI s/p BMS ___ - no chest discomfort or anginal 
【251】equivalents on arrival. At baseline patient can walk up 15 
【252】flights of stairs without Dyspnea or Angina. He was continued on 
【253】his home aspirin, statin. ACEi and Imdur held in the setting of 
【254】hypotension.  
【255】
【256】# Pituitary Tumor Removal - in the ___, on Chronic Prednisone at 
【257】home, pt notes consistent use. As above patient was initially 
【258】given stress dose steroids but was then transitioned to his home 
【259】prednisone.  
【260】
【261】# Hypothyroidism - per patient recently stopped Levothyroxine as 
【262】directed by Cardiologist. TSH wnl this admission. Will need to 
【263】follow up in clinic.

【19】
【20】 
【21】History of Present Illness:
【22】___ is a ___ man who initially presented to 
【23】surgical ___ clinic on ___ for evaluation of right upper 
【24】back invasive melanoma.
【25】
【26】Mr. ___ apparently had been seen in Dermatology in the past 
【27】for psoriasis but he has no previous history of skin cancer. He 
【28】indicates that he was aware of a lesion of the right upper back 
【29】for at least ___ years, which over the past few weeks became 
【30】more raised at the center and somewhat pruritic.  ___ is 
【31】quite convinced that he had picked at the lesion very shortly 
【32】before his biopsy procedure.  He did not have any spontaneous 
【33】bleeding otherwise. 
【34】
【35】___ also showed me today a large very suspicious nodule of 
【36】the right medial calf which probably represents a 
【37】keratoacanthoma or squamous cell cancer present for an 
【38】indeterminate length of time.  He thinks that it has been
【39】progressive within the past two weeks.
【40】
【41】He underwent shave biopsy of the right upper back lesion on 
【42】___.  The pathology, as reviewed again today with our 
【43】dedicated dermatopathology group, shows an invasive melanoma 
【44】with a minimal thickness of 0.65 mm with an involved deep and 
【45】peripheral margin.  The lesion extended to ___ level III. 
【46】There was 1 mitosis present per mm2 with mitoses scattered 
【47】throughout the specimen.  There was a small area with overlying 
【48】scale which could be interpreted as focal ulceration, but our 
【49】group felt overall it was most consistent with the patient's 
【50】history of trauma.  The lesion appears to arise within a 
【51】preexisting nevus.  It was positive for Melan-A and HMB-45.  On 
【52】the same date, a biopsy of the right helix was performed showing 
【53】epidermal acanthosis with an involved margin.
【54】
【55】To a review of systems, ___ does not smoke cigarettes.  He 
【56】has never undergone colonoscopy.  A 10-point review was 
【57】otherwise not suggestive of metastatic disease.
【58】 
【59】Past Medical History:
【60】- HIV 
【61】- ? Schizoaffective disorder
【62】- Alcoholism 
【63】- Psoriasis 
【64】- Hypertension
【65】- Hepatitis B, resolved per patient report
【66】- Peyronie's disease
【67】- Hyperlipidemia
【68】- Obesity
【69】- Gout
【70】- LSIL in anal PAP
【71】- ___ cyst   
【72】
【73】

【75】___
【76】Family History:
【77】Mother died of pancreatic cancer at age ___. Father died of old 
【78】age at ___. He was diagnosed with prostate cancer ___ years 
【79】earlier.
【80】
【81】 
【82】Physical Exam:
【83】On examination, ___ was a cooperative man in no distress. 
【84】The blood pressure was 156/90.  The heart rate was 70 and 
【85】regular.  He weighed 213 pounds and was 5 feet ___ inches 
【86】tall. The temperature was 98.4.  The chest was clear.  He was in 
【87】a sinus rhythm and had no murmurs.  He had small psoriatic 
【88】plaques scattered throughout his body.  Overlying the right 
【89】upper back, he had a 1 cm macular pink lesion with a central 
【90】pigmented papule
【91】measuring perhaps 3 mm with evidence of a small shave biopsy at 
【92】the tip.  The majority of the lesion remained intact, however. 
【93】He had nothing to suggest satellitosis or in-transit disease. 
【94】Overlying the right anterior medial calf, he had a 1 cm 
【95】non-pigmented papular lesion with a central pore highly
【96】suggestive of a keratoacanthoma or squamous cell carcinoma.  The 
【97】surrounding skin laxity was poor.  He had no cervical, 
【98】supraclavicular, axillary, epitrochlear, inguinal or femoral 
【99】adenopathy.  The abdomen was soft and without evidence of 
【100】ascites or any type of secondary findings of portal 
【101】hypertension.  His liver and spleen were nonpalpable.  His 
【102】femoral and distal pulses were full.  He had no focal neurologic 
【103】or musculoskeletal findings.
【104】 
【105】Pertinent Results:
【106】As listed in HPI.
【107】 
【108】Brief Hospital Course:
【109】The patient presented as a same day admission for surgery. The 
【110】patient was taken to the operating room for wide excision of 
【111】right upper back melanoma and right supraclavicular lymph node 
【112】biopsy, which the patient tolerated well. For full details of 
【113】the procedure please see the separately dictated operative 
【114】report. The patient was taken from the OR to the PACU in stable 
【115】condition and after satisfactory recovery from anesthesia was 
【116】transferred to the floor. The patient was initially given IV 
【117】fluids and IV pain medications, and progressed to a regular diet 
【118】and oral medications by POD#1. The patient was given 
【119】perioperative antibiotics and anticoagulation per routine. The 
【120】patient's home medications were continued throughout this 
【121】hospitalization. The ___ hospital course was otherwise 
【122】unremarkable.
【123】At the time of discharge the patient's pain was well controlled 
【124】with oral medications, dressings were clean/dry/intact, and the 
【125】patient was voiding/moving bowels spontaneously. The patient 
【126】will follow up in one week with Dr. ___ routine. A thorough 
【127】discussion was had with the patient regarding the diagnosis and 
【128】expected post-discharge course including reasons to call the 
【129】office or return to the hospital, and all questions were 
【130】answered. The patient was also given written instructions 
【131】concerning precautionary instructions and the appropriate 
【132】follow-up care. The patient expressed readiness for discharge.
【133】
【134】

【137】2. Atenolol 75 mg PO DAILY

【162】Home

【165】Right upper back invasive melanoma

【172】
【173】 
【174】Discharge Instructions:
【175】It was a pleasure caring for you during your stay at ___ 
【176】___. You underwent a wide excision of right 
【177】upper back melanoma and right supraclavicular lymph node biopsy 
【178】and have adequate pain control and tolerated a regular diet, and 
【179】are ready to return home to continue your recovery. The 
【180】following is a summary of discharge instructions. 
【181】
【182】MEDICATIONS 
【183】1. Please resume all home medications, unless specifically 
【184】advised not to take a particular medication. Please take any new 
【185】medications as prescribed.
【186】2. Please take all pain medications as prescribed, as needed. 
【187】You may not drive or operate heavy machinery while taking 
【188】narcotic pain medications. You may also take acetaminophen 
【189】(Tylenol) as directed, but do not exceed 4000 mg in one day. 
【190】3. An over-the-counter stool softener such as Colace (100 mg 
【191】twice daily) is recommended to prevent constipation while on 
【192】narcotic pain medication.
【193】
【194】WOUND CARE
【195】1. Monitor the wounds for signs of infection, including redness 
【196】that is spreading or increased drainage from wounds. Please call 
【197】Dr. ___ if you experience any of these symptoms.
【198】2. You may shower immediately with your dressing on.  You may 
【199】remove your dressing 72 hours (3 days) after day of surgery.
【200】
【201】ACTIVITY
【202】1. Walk several times a day. No strenuous activity until cleared 
【203】by Dr. ___. 
【204】2. No showering until cleared by Dr. ___ sponge baths only.
【205】 
【206】Call the office IMMEDIATELY if you have any of the following:  
【207】1. Signs of infection: fever with chills, increased redness, 
【208】swelling, warmth or tenderness at the surgical site, or unusual 
【209】drainage from the incision(s).  
【210】2. A large amount of bleeding from the incision(s) or drain(s).  
【211】
【212】3. Fever greater than 101.5 F  
【213】4. Severe pain NOT relieved by your medication.  
【214】  
【215】Return to the ER if:  
【216】* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
【217】medications.  
【218】* If you have shaking chills, fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
【219】degrees or 38 (C) degrees, increased redness, swelling or 
【220】discharge from incision, chest pain, shortness of breath, or 
【221】anything else that is troubling you.  
【222】* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
【223】concern you.  
【224】 
【225】Followup Instructions:
【226】___

【197】Mr ___ is a ___ year old man with history of T1DM and

【201】ACUTE ISSUES:
【202】# Gastroenteritis: Given sudden onset of pain, fever and 
【203】frequency of n/v/d, initial concern was for an infectious 
【204】gastroenteritis such as norovirus. However, stool culture, c. 
【205】diff and norovirus were all negative.  Initial lipase was 
【206】negative. While DKA may have be a possible cause, symptoms 
【207】persisted after resolution of DKA. Gastroparesis was another 
【208】alternative diagnosis, though less likely given acute onset, 
【209】lower abd pain and diarrhea. He improved slowly with supportive 
【210】care. He initially required IV antiemetics and pain medications, 
【211】but was able to successfully transition to orals. By the time of 
【212】discharge, Mr ___ was able to eat and drink without 
【213】difficulty and he had no further nausea and vomiting. 
【214】
【215】# T1DM: Hyperglycemia in the setting of acute infection with AG 
【216】metabolic acidosis and ketonuria was consistent with mild DKA. 
【217】DKA resolved with SQ insulin and IVF resuscitation.  Insulin 
【218】regimen titrated in setting of poor PO and N/V with 
【219】gastroenteritis as above. 
【220】
【221】# ___: Presented with Cr 1.9, up from baseline 1.0.  Quickly 
【222】resolved with IVF, thus was likely prerenal in nature due to GI 
【223】losses and hyperglycemia. Creatinine remained at baseline for 
【224】the remainder of hospitalization.

【185】Lower Extremity Angioplasty/Stent Discharge Instructions
【186】
【187】Medications:
【188】Take Aspirin 325mg (enteric coated) once daily 
【189】If instructed, take Plavix (Clopidogrel) 75mg once daily
【190】Continue all other medications you were taking before surgery, 
【191】unless otherwise directed
【192】You make take Tylenol or prescribed pain medications for any 
【193】post procedure pain or discomfort
【194】
【195】What to expect when you go home:
【196】It is normal to have slight swelling of the legs:
【197】Elevate your leg above the level of your heart (use ___ 
【198】pillows or a recliner) every ___ hours throughout the day and at 
【199】night
【200】Avoid prolonged periods of standing or sitting without your 
【201】legs elevated
【202】It is normal to feel tired and have a decreased appetite, your 
【203】appetite will return with time 
【204】Drink plenty of fluids and eat small frequent meals
【205】It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber, 
【206】lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to 
【207】maintain your strength and assist in wound healing
【208】To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool 
【209】softener while taking pain medication
【210】
【211】What activities you can and cannot do:
【212】When you go home, you may walk and go up and down stairs
【213】You may shower (let the soapy water run over groin incision, 
【214】rinse and pat dry)
【215】Your incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small 
【216】amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing or 
【217】band aid over the area that is draining, as needed
【218】No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 lbs) for 
【219】1 week (to allow groin puncture to heal)
【220】After 1 week, you may resume sexual activity
【221】After 1 week, gradually increase your activities and distance 
【222】walked as you can tolerate
【223】No driving until you are no longer taking pain medications

【258】# Paranoia:
【259】Patient with reports of identity theft revolving around online 
【260】dating (WhatsApp), with concern that she had given away her 
【261】social security number to someone she had intended to marry. 
【262】However, upon further discussion, she is very worried that she

【265】websites. She was fearful that when she spoke to her mother on 
【266】the phone it may have not been her mother, and also reports 
【267】noticing ___ such as what was written in Whatsapp appearing 
【268】as actual conversations between her and hospital staff. She was

【270】detection software through the ID badges of hospital staff.

【272】including negative HIV, RPR; TSH and vitamin B12 WNL, MRI 
【273】without abnormality to explain symptoms, EEG without 
【274】epileptiform activity, and tox screen negative. Hepatitis panel

【276】although difficult to tell colonization v. infection. Psychiatry 
【277】recommended starting olanzapine 2.5 mg QHS which patient 
【278】tolerated. Psychiatry did not feel that she needed inpatient 
【279】treatment and that she was safe for discharge home. Outpatient

【285】had met through data apps. Please see notes for details of 
【286】report. She was referred to ___ Violence Prevention and 
【287】Recovery. She declined reporting to police. Negative HIV, RPR.

【291】# Concern for starvation ketosis

【293】ketones in urine and report of potentially decreased PO intake

【295】paranoid delusions, and concern for dehydration in setting of

【300】# History of ileal conduit
【301】# Purple urine bag syndrome

【91】Brief Hospital Course:
【92】Patient underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Patient was 
【93】transferred to the PACU in stable condition with JPx1. 
【94】Overnight, patient put out bilious output from her JP drain. On 
【95】POD2, patient had JP output of bilious fluids. Patient was taken 
【96】to ERCP where the CBD was unable to be cannulated, a PD stent 
【97】was placed. However, on POD3, repeat ERCP was performed with 
【98】successful cannulation of CBD with stent placement.
【99】
【100】Patient was advanced to a bariatric stage II diet but she had 
【101】continued right upper quadrant abdominal pain and focal 
【102】peritonitis.  An ultrasound was performed on ___ with evidence 
【103】of a 2 cm biloma in the right upper quadrant.  The patient's 
【104】total bilirubin began to rise and she had a growing leukocytosis 
【105】with intermittent fevers.  Her INR rose to 4.2 and a CT scan was 
【106】performed with evidence of a 7 x 4.7 x 9.3 cm bilious collection 
【107】in the right upper quadrant.  She was given vitamin K for 
【108】correction of her INR.  The following day she was sent to 
【109】interventional radiology with drainage of 120 cc of purulent 
【110】bilious fluid, a drain was placed in the collection.  Her 
【111】antibiotics were broadened to cefepime and Flagyl.  She was 
【112】again sent for an ERCP with sphincterotomy and stent placement 
【113】to help decompress the bile duct.
【114】
【115】Her home medications were resumed when the patient was started 
【116】back in a bariatric stage II diet which was well-tolerated.  A 
【117】CT scan was again performed on ___ with evidence of a 1.6 x 
【118】5.1 collection anterior to her stomach.  Interventional 
【119】radiology was again consulted for possible aspiration and 
【120】drainage of this collection, however this was not possible due 
【121】to the location.  Infectious disease was consulted for 
【122】assistance with management of the patient's antibiotic regimen 
【123】and they recommended broadening the patient from cefepime and 
【124】Flagyl to Zosyn IV.  Upon starting broad-spectrum antibiotics 
【125】the patient's leukocytosis began to resolve, her abdominal pain 
【126】improved, and over the subsequent days her bilious drainage from 
【127】her ___ placed drain began to decline daily.  PICC line was 
【128】placed in anticipation of the patient being discharged on 
【129】long-term IV antibiotics after discharge.
【130】
【131】Prior to discharge the patient was tolerating a regular diet 
【132】without any nausea or vomiting, her pain is well controlled on 
【133】oral pain medications.  She was afebrile and did not have a 
【134】leukocytosis.  Her PICC line was in good position and she was 
【135】receiving IV antibiotics.  She is ambulating at her baseline, 
【136】her right upper quadrant drains were still producing small 
【137】amounts of bilious output.  She was discharged home with 
【138】infusion services as well as visiting nurse care for IV 
【139】antibiotics as well as drain care.  She will follow-up with a 
【140】CAT scan as well as labs on ___ in anticipation of the clinic 
【141】follow-up with Dr. ___ on ___.  She will also follow-up 
【142】with infectious diseases in clinic following her CT scan at the 
【143】end of ___.

【167】You were admitted to the hospital for a gastroporesis flare. 
【168】Your pain was controlled with IV narcotic medications. You 
【169】received a medicine called erythromycin to help improve your 
【170】gastroporesis, which only lasted 2 days. You were started on 
【171】neurontin, valium, methadone and dilaudid for pain. Your gastric 
【172】pacer was interrogated by Dr. ___ and is in working order. 
【173】.
【174】You will need to follow up with Dr. ___ an endoscopy on 
【175】Wendesday with botox injection. 
【176】.
【177】Please be aware that you should not drive on narcotic agents 
【178】like methadone or dilaudid. Please do not drink alcohol on these 
【179】medications. Stop taking dilaudid, methadone and valium if you 
【180】develop confusion, fatigue, or change in your breathing pattern. 
【181】Be sure to take over the counter stool softeners like senna and 
【182】colace to maintain regular bowel movements because these 
【183】medications can be quite constipating. 
【184】.
【185】You should taper off your dilaudid for pain over the next ___ 
【186】days and only use methadone, valium and neurontin after that. 
【187】For now, you can take 4 mg every 4 hours, then you should try to 
【188】take every 6 hours, then every 8 hours, then twice daily, and 
【189】then once daily and then off.
【190】.

【85】bone marrow biopsy performed. This reveals a hypocellular

【87】predominant bone marrow with no morphological evidence of

【96】isolated
【97】reduction in DLCO suggests a perfusion limitation. 
【98】- ___: Pre-transplant bone marrow biopsy performed. This
【99】reveals a hypocellular bone marrow with maturing trilineage
【100】hematopoiesis, and no evidence of involvement by AML. The
【101】karyotype was normal, and Flt3 ITD testing was negative.

【272】Brief Hospital Course:
【273】Ms ___ is a ___ y/o F with Flt3 ITD mutated Acute Myelogenous
【274】Leukemia in the setting of heterozygosity for GATA2 deficiency,
【275】status-post induction therapy with 7+3 and midostaurin x 2
【276】cycles, s/p consolidation with HiDAC/midostaurin, now presenting
【277】for allotransplant from a matched unrelated donor. Her course 
【278】was complicated by acute neck swelling due to mucositis that 
【279】required broad spectrum abx with resolution. She also developed 
【280】diarrhea that was concerning for graft versus host disease, 
【281】which was treated with steroids and improved dramatically. 
【282】
【283】ACTIVE ISSUES:
【284】==============
【285】
【286】#AML
【287】#S/p allo transplant (___)
【288】Patient recently completed consolidation therapy with 
【289】HiDAC/midostaurin and presented for scheduled admission for 
【290】allotransplant from matched unrelated donor after completion of 
【291】ablative therapy with Flu/Bu/ATG. Patient's ablative therapy 
【292】course complicated by Palmar/Plantar Erythrodysesthesia (as 
【293】below) and severe nausea/vomiting requiring zofran. Fluconazole 
【294】D/C'd after dose ___ iso transaminitis (as below) and was 
【295】switched to micafungin for fungal ppx, and ultimately to 
【296】cresemba. She developed severe mucositis while neutropenic (as 
【297】below). Over time, her counts recovered, and then she developed 
【298】leukocytosis and thrombocytosis. A thorough infectious workup 
【299】was completed (cultures, CT torso/neck, C Diff pcr) which was 
【300】all negative and the patient continued to feel well. Peripheral 
【301】cytogenics confirmed donor leukocytes. At the time of discharge 
【302】the patient felt well and there was no clear source for the 
【303】persistent leukocytosis, which should be monitored over time. 
【304】She will be continued on tacrolimus with goal of ___ (.5 mg BID 
【305】at time of discharge). She will also be continued on Acyclovir, 
【306】cresemba ppx.
【307】
【308】# Diarrhea
【309】# Acute GVHD
【310】Patient with new diarrhea the morning of ___, watery with ___
【311】episodes. CDiff Neagtive. Concern for GVHD -- improved with 30 
【312】IV
【313】methylpred BID, now on oral steroids (tapering) without
【314】further diarrhea. She was originally started on trial that 
【315】included Itacitinib for GVHD, but the drug was discontinued 
【316】given the patients ongoing leykocytosis of unclear etiology. She 
【317】will be discharged on 15 mg prednisone, which will be tapered as 
【318】tolerated. She was discharged without any significant amount of 
【319】diarrhea. Given how quickly her symptoms improved, it was 
【320】unclear if the patient truly had GVHD vs some other cause of 
【321】diarrhea. She did not receive endoscopy or tissue sample for 
【322】diagnosis. 
【323】
【324】#Mucositis
【325】OP noted to be erythematous w/ multiple small lesions Transplant 
【326】Day 6. Eating became difficult and patient was not finding 
【327】adequate pain relief from po pain meds and mouthwashes. Started 
【328】morphine pca and converted meds
【329】to IV where able. Also started TPN while unable to tolerate 
【330】regular diet. She gradually had improvement in symptoms and was 
【331】able to resume PO over time, and TPN was discontinued. 
【332】
【333】#Neck Swelling
【334】Patient developed diffuse neck swelling overnight ___. Swelling 
【335】was not causing patient pain, not compromising respiration, no 
【336】overlying skin changes. Most likely this represented a local 
【337】response to patient's severe mucositis and subsequent 
【338】inflammation aggravating surrounding tissues. CT neck w/ 
【339】contrast revealed soft tissue edema from skull base to C4 and 
【340】retropharyngeal fluid collection. She was ___ transferred to 
【341】the ICU on ___ due to concern for airway; she remained stable 
【342】overnight without concern for airway and ENT deemed no further 
【343】intervention including drainage was necessary. She was started 
【344】on
【345】Vancomycin 1000 mg q12hr, Meropenem 1000 mg IV Q8H, Micafungin
【346】100 mg IV Q24H and completed a 10 day course with improvement in 
【347】neck swelling.
【348】
【349】#Constipation
【350】Likely related to chemotherapy and now increasing dose of opioid 
【351】pain medication for mucositis. Pt was unable to tolerate po 
【352】bowel regimen with mucositis and was given methylnaltrexone in 
【353】setting of high doses of opioids being used. 
【354】
【355】#Transammonitis
【356】Most likely iso fluconazole ppx. Transitioned to Micafungin ___ 
【357】with downtrending of her LFTs.
【358】
【359】#Palmar/Plantar Erythrodysesthesia
【360】Patient with erythematous palms and plantar aspects of feet on 
【361】___. Also experiencing tingling in palms and burning
【362】pain in feet. Pain slightly relieved with ice. No overlying skin 
【363】changes other than erythema. Most likely cause is fludarabine. 
【364】Not a common culprit for this condition but case reports exist 
【365】in the literature. Patient had already finished fludarabine 
【366】course by time symptoms developed. Pain and erythema resolved 
【367】over the course of her admission with use of topical emollient 
【368】cream, and topical steroid cream.
【369】

【371】===============
【372】
【373】#Thrombocytopenia
【374】#Anemia
【375】Chronic in setting of malignancy/chemotherapy. Patient was 
【376】transfused for Hgb < 7, and plt < 10. Lovenox was discontinued 
【377】when plt count fell below 50, and restarted once counts 
【378】recovered.. 
【379】
【380】#Hypertension
【381】Home metoprolol succ 75mg daily continued throughout admission. 
【382】She remained hypertensive, and 30 mg nifedipine ER was added to 
【383】her regimen with good effect. 
【384】
【385】#Fertility
【386】Has been receiving monthly Lupron injections per OB/GYN. 
【387】___, and ___. Will need further follow up 
【388】with OB-GYN to further concern fertility preserving therapies.

【394】Held home Adderall, which can be continued at discharge.

【506】Discharge Instructions:
【507】Dear Ms. ___,  
【508】
【509】It was a pleasure caring of you at ___.  
【510】
【511】WHY WAS I IN THE HOSPITAL?  
【512】- You were admitted to the hospital for your scheduled bone 
【513】marrow transplant.  
【514】
【515】WHAT HAPPENED TO ME IN THE HOSPITAL?  
【516】- You were prepared for your transplant with a chemotherapy 
【517】regimen designed to deplete the cells in your bone marrow. Once 
【518】you completed that course of chemotherapy we transfused you the 
【519】transplant cells.
【520】- After receiving the transplant cells we gave you medications 
【521】to help the transplant stick in your body, monitored you closely 
【522】for complications from those medications and from the transplant 
【523】itself, and treated your symptoms as best we could.
【524】- You developed redness and pain in the palms of your hands and 
【525】the soles of your feet which we treated with topical creams
【526】- You developed pain in your mouth and throat (mucositis). We 
【527】treated you symptomatically with pain medications by mouth 
【528】initially and then by IV when the pain was uncontrolled with 
【529】oral medications. We also gave you nutrition through your IV 
【530】when the pain became too bad to allow you to eat normally. 
【531】- When you developed a fever while neutropenic we gave you 
【532】antibiotics through your IV until your neutrophil count 
【533】recovered.
【534】- You were given steroids after you developed diarrhea. 
【535】
【536】WHAT SHOULD I DO AFTER I LEAVE THE HOSPITAL?  
【537】- Continue to take all your medicines and keep your 
【538】appointments.  
【539】
【540】We wish you the best!  
【541】
【542】Sincerely,  
【543】
【544】Your ___ Team

【159】# RLE Cellulitis vs. Soft Tissue Infection: Recent imaging at 
【160】___ showed an MRI without signs of osteomyelitis on ___ and 
【161】on prior admission here at ___ in early ___ triple phase 
【162】bone scan and MRI both negative for osteomyelitis. Rising 
【163】leukocytosis, newly elevated CRP (1.0 on ___ -> 8.6), and 
【164】report of chills and sweats raised concern for early infection. 
【165】She was evaluated by orthopedics, who recommended that there was 
【166】no need for urgent intervention; they advised her to weight bear 
【167】as tolerated. She was given vancomycin initially, but per ID 
【168】consult, she was switched to PO cephalexin. Based on the midly 
【169】elevated CRP and no evidence of osteomyelitis on bone scan, it 
【170】was felt that this was a cellulitis. In responsive to 
【171】cephalexin, the erythema, pain and edema decreased. She was able 
【172】to ambulate without assistance. Her white count decreased as 
【173】well from level at admission. She was given morphine for pain 
【174】(for assistance with neuropathic pain), as well as tylenol and 
【175】NSAIDs. She was asked to follow-up with Infectious Disease in 
【176】one week, continuing the course of cephalexin until that time.

【115】Brief Hospital Course:
【116】PSYCH:
【117】On arrival to this unit the patient was extremely agitated and 
【118】irritated by his nurse but does calm down when the room is 
【119】cleared out and he is able to speak to his resident.  He was 
【120】very tearful and labile, still irritated.  He was dramatic, 
【121】saying "you are my saviour."  He was grandiose, for example, 
【122】saying "I have so much going on, I have skills upon skills."  He 
【123】also seemed to display some splitting, telling his resident "my 
【124】wife's a nurse, she's a better nurse than anyone I've 
【125】encountered here."  Every provider discussed is described as  
【126】either  wonderful or horrible.  His thought process was 
【127】tangential with some subtle loosened associations.  He denied 
【128】suicidal ideation throughout his admission. It was ultimately 
【129】felt with additional collateral from his wife and through 
【130】ongoing assessment that Mr. ___ was presenting with a manic 
【131】episode in the context of recent cocaine abuse. 
【132】
【133】Though the patient was help seeking and admitted voluntarily 
【134】without a ___, and the rules associated with signing a CV 
【135】were explained in detail, as soon as the patient signed the CV 
【136】he started to demand that he leave immediately and be 
【137】transferred to another unit, although it was explained that Deac 
【138】4 is the only psychiatric unit in the hospital.  He continued to 
【139】grow increasingly uncooperative, agitated and threatening 
【140】towards staff,  and required a chemical and physical restraint 
【141】his first evening on the unit.  He was then placed on security 
【142】continuous observation for safety overnight. His behavior did 
【143】improve and he was returned to Q15min checks for safety. Mr. 
【144】___ effexor and ___ were discontinued on admission 
【145】due to concern for mania.  His lamictal was also stopped. He was 
【146】initally treated with seroquel to target his manic symptoms, but 
【147】this was discontinued as it was too sedating. He was also given 
【148】haldol (with cogentin) due to his degree of agitation upon 
【149】admission. As he improved wth treatment, the haldol was switched 
【150】to risperidone 2mg BID with PRN ativan for agitation, anxiety 
【151】and insomnia. He found the risperidone very helpful, tolerating 
【152】it well without sdeation. It was unclear during his 
【153】hospitalization if Mr. ___ manic episode was triggered by 
【154】substance (antidepressants and cocaine) or if he indeed suffers 
【155】from bipolar disorder. This was discussed in detail with he and 
【156】his wife and they understand the importance of close follow up 
【157】with his psyhciatrist to determine this through time and to 
【158】evaluate the efficacy and tolerability of risperdal over hte 
【159】next few days to weeks. An antipsychotic was felt to be 
【160】necessary at this time due to his degree of agitation in the 
【161】hospital, but this will likley need to be adjusted through time 
【162】and the utilty of lamictal should be reconsidered. He and his 
【163】wife will also both monitor for signs of effexor withdrawal. So 
【164】far he has been tolateing the discontinuation of his 
【165】antidepressants well. Psychoeducation was provided about the 
【166】symnptoms of mania vs ADD/ADHD as the aptient was initally 
【167】requesting a stimulant medication. 
【168】
【169】Mr. ___ improved dramatically by discharge and was able to 
【170】engage in meaningful discussion surrounding his mental health, 
【171】substance abuse, and treatment plan for the future. He was 
【172】pleasant, cooperative, and understood the importance of avoiding 
【173】cocaine and mental helath follow up. His organization, insight, 
【174】and judhement all improved. He slept at night and was no longer 
【175】irritable. He and his wife both strongly requested discharge as 
【176】soon as possible, as it was felt that the ___ hospital was 
【177】not a productive enviornment ultimatly for Mr. ___. His wife 
【178】will continue to closely monitor his medications (as she has 
【179】been through time) and both were agreeable to transition to a 
【180】partial hosptial program, understanding risk of relapse and 
【181】emergency signs/symptoms to seek help. At no point during his 
【182】hospitalization was suicidality a concern, and there was no 
【183】evidence of failure to care for himself. 
【184】
【185】RISK ASSESSMENT: While Mr. ___ continues to be at risk of 
【186】harm to self and inability to care forself given his 
【187】impulsivity, mood lability and chronic substance abuse, his risk 
【188】has been substantially mitigated during his hospital stay. His 
【189】mood has improved and he has gained more insight into this.  He 
【190】has remained drug free during his hospital stay, is determined 
【191】to continue sobriety as an outpatient, and will be following up 
【192】with an intensive outpatient dual diagnosis program on discharge 
【193】for further observation and management.  He will additionally 
【194】beable to acquire more tools and utilize coping skills learned 
【195】during this IOP.  He has a supportive wife who, in addition to 
【196】the patient, has been educated on the warning signs and symptoms 
【197】of mania and all agree to a plan to call the patient's providers 
【198】or return to the hospital if these symptoms return or worsen.  
【199】Mr. ___ provider has been updated on the 
【200】patient's progress and outpatient plan and will be following up 
【201】closely with him.  Mr. ___ was adament in denying suicidal 
【202】and homicidal ideation throughout his hospitalization and was 
【203】motivated for care through out.

【171】Brief Hospital Course:
【172】Mr. ___ is a ___ with history of Alzheimer's dementia, 
【173】recent diagnosis of superficial RLE thrombosis on Eliquis, MI 
【174】s/p quadruple bypass, afib on digoxin due to h/o massive GI 
【175】bleed, and CVA who presented with progressive cognitive decline 
【176】and failure to tolerate POs. 
【177】Initially, reversible causes for dementia were ruled out. An 
【178】infectious workup was conducted, and urine culture was positive 
【179】for E. coli and therefore treated with IV Ceftriaxone for 5 
【180】days. The overall presentation was thought to be most concerning 
【181】for progressive end stage dementia. A goals of care conversation 
【182】with his son and healthcare proxy guided decision-making to not 
【183】pursue placement of a G-tube. He was discharged to ___ 
【184】rehabilitation, per recommendations from physical therapy. Dr. 
【185】___ primary care doctor, has agreed to continue the 
【186】goals of care discussion, specifically around his code status, 
【187】after discharge.
【188】
【189】#Inability to tolerate POs: This was thought to be either due to 
【190】transient delirium, progression of dementia and resulting 
【191】disinterest in eating, or more mechanical causes such as 
【192】dysphagia or odynophagia. Given appropriate management of 
【193】secretions, obstruction was felt to be unlikely. Speech and 
【194】swallow evaluated Mr. ___, and felt that there was no 
【195】concern for a mechanical process. Transient delirium in the 
【196】setting of a UTI was possible, although unlikely given no 
【197】resolution of symptoms after antibiotic treatment. This was felt 
【198】to therefore be most likely disinterest in eating due to 
【199】progression of end stage dementia. His willingness to take small 
【200】amounts of POs with his son feeding him suggested that 
【201】reorientation and familiar people/environments were helping.
【202】
【203】#Progressive cognitive decline, Goals of care: Acute causes of 
【204】cognitive decline, including MI or PE, were rule out (no EKG 
【205】changes, no tachycardia, evidence of RH strain, or respiratory 
【206】distress). LENIs showed interval improvement in superficial RLE 
【207】thrombosis. A stroke or vascular dementia were ruled out given 
【208】negative NCHCT, and then negative head MRI. Reversible dementia 
【209】was ruled out with normal B12, RPR, and TSH levels. Transient 
【210】delirium in the setting of infection was postulated, but CXR was 
【211】negative. UA was negative, but a urine culture showed >100,000 
【212】colonies of E. coli. Although he is incontinent to urine and 
【213】stool, this was treated as a complicated UTI due to his 
【214】worsening mental status with IV Ceftriaxone x5 days with some 
【215】improvement in his mental status. Electrolytes were consistently 
【216】within normal limits. Digoxin level was 0.4. This was held on 
【217】admission, and stopped at discharge in consultation with his 
【218】PCP, as he was in sinus rhythm and the risks were felt to 
【219】outweigh the benefits. Geriatrics was consulted, and agreed with 
【220】the workup and recommendations. A goals of care discussion with 
【221】his son and healthcare proxy resulted in no G-tube consideration 
【222】and understanding about the prognosis. He expressed considerable 
【223】insight and understanding into his father's condition, and felt 
【224】that he may soon end up at hospice. He also felt that 
【225】intubation, chest compressions, and shock would be very 
【226】traumatic, and likely not in line with his father's current 
【227】goals of care. However, he strongly felt that his father would 
【228】have wanted to be "given a chance," and felt that he needed more 
【229】time to think about changing his father from Full code to 
【230】DNR/DNI. So, he was discharged to ___ rehab, Full code, 
【231】with plans for Dr. ___ to continue the discussion about his 
【232】code status (per conversation with Dr. ___. He was continued 
【233】on his home dose of Namenda at discharge.
【234】
【235】#RLE superficial thrombosis: he was on home Eliquis (last dose 
【236】___. However, he was not tolerating POs while admitted, and 
【237】was unable to take this medication although it was continued. 
【238】This was discontinued at discharge, in consultation with his

【241】superficial thrombus.
【242】
【243】#Hypertension: Blood pressures were within SBP 130-160, with 
【244】occasional episodes to 180. Toprol was switched to Metoprolol to

【204】10.2. CT scan at ___ showed diverticulosis, no aortoenteric 
【205】fistula (known AAA). INR was 1.5 on admission; warfarin was 
【206】held. Hgb was trended and decreased from 7.5 to 6.7 on HD1 and 
【207】he was transfused 1U PRBCs. He was seen by GI and underwent 
【208】colonosocpy on ___ which showed multiple diverticula but no 
【209】masses. Patient was found to be actively bleeding during 
【210】colonoscopy, but unfortunately no definitive source was 
【211】identified and thus no intervention performed. Patient initially 
【212】on clear liquid diet, but was transitioned to full diet post 
【213】procedure and did well. Patient continued to have intermittent 
【214】episodes of bloody stools and bright red blood per rectum in 
【215】subsequent days, but hemoglobin remained stable throughout 
【216】hospitalization. 
【217】
【218】Patient counseled that he may continue to bleed at home, and 
【219】will likely require frequent lab work and possibly occasional 
【220】transfusions as outpatient. He was discharged with close PCP and 
【221】GI follow up. 
【222】

【224】to risk of overt GI bleed. His PCP stated he would address this 
【225】at future visit.

【228】orthopedic surgery) and multiple PE in ___ (unclear 
【229】circumstances). His warfarin was held for GIB, but he wore

【234】
【235】#Atrial Fibrillation: Patient has atrial fibrillation status 
【236】post PPM for SSS. Patient's Warfarin held throughout admission 
【237】in setting of GI bleed. Metoprolol was initially held as patient 
【238】was hypotensive, but blood pressures improved once normal diet 
【239】was resumed and patient was re-started on home dose. Patient 
【240】remained well rate controlled throughout admission. 
【241】Anticoagulation held at discharge, and given patient's CHADS 
【242】score 5, he was instructed to discuss possibility of resuming 
【243】anticoagulation therapy with PCP as outpatient. This was

【35】referred to ENT at ___ and had bilateral tympanostomy tubes 
【36】placed.  Prior to this he had no history of chronic ear 
【37】infections and does not recall ear infections as a child.  
【38】Despite the tubes his pain persisted with each subsequent 
【39】bariatric treatment and he now declines to finish his course 
【40】there.  Over the last week he noted subjective fevers nightly 
【41】with drenching night sweats and increasing pain of the right ear 
【42】in particular.

【44】Upon arrival to the ED, his initial vitals were 73 118/74 15 
【45】99%.  Podiatry saw him and felt the wounds looked chronic and 
【46】stable, recommending WBAT to heals (apparently quite 
【47】noncompliant with pressure avoidance), and a 10d course of abx 
【48】with outpt followup.  ENT evaluated due to concern for otitis 
【49】externa. Their exam revealed probable otitis media that was 
【50】chronic and they confirmed patency of the tubes.  A CT of the 
【51】orbits showed evidence of likely chronic mastoiditis, though due

【53】antipseudomonal IV abx.  He received cefepime and got an oral 
【54】dose of cipro that I suspect was intended to be a ciprodex drop 
【55】order.  He has an allergy to levaquin but has tolerated the 
【56】cipro thus far.

【190】oxycodone. On post-operative day 1, her urine output was 
【191】adequate, so her foley was removed, she passed a trial of void, 
【192】and was voiding spontaneously. Her diet was advanced without 
【193】difficulty, and she was transitioned to oral oxycodone, 
【194】ibuprofen, acetaminophen.

【197】were monitored and she was continued on Lantus and saxenda. In 
【198】regards to her hypertension, she was continued on lipitor and 
【199】lisinopril.
【200】
【201】By post-operative day 1, she was tolerating a regular diet, 
【202】voiding spontaneously, ambulating independently, and pain was 
【203】controlled with oral medications. She was then discharged home 
【204】in stable condition with outpatient follow-up scheduled.

【267】Discharge Instructions:
【268】Dear ___,
【269】
【270】You were admitted to the gynecology service after your 
【271】procedure. You have recovered well and the team believes you are 
【272】ready to be discharged home. Please call Dr. ___ office 
【273】with any questions or concerns. Please follow the instructions 
【274】below.
【275】
【276】General instructions:
【277】* Take your medications as prescribed.
【278】* Do not drive while taking narcotics.
【279】* Take a stool softener such as colace while taking narcotics to 
【280】prevent constipation.
【281】* Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol.
【282】* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs.
【283】* No strenuous activity until your post-op appointment.
【284】* Nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no douching, no sex) for 3 
【285】months.
【286】* No heavy lifting of objects >10 lbs for 6 weeks.
【287】* You may eat a regular diet.
【288】* You may walk up and down stairs.
【289】
【290】Incision care:
【291】* You may shower and allow soapy water to run over incision; no 
【292】scrubbing of incision. No tub baths for 6 weeks.
【293】* Since you have steri-strips, leave them on. They will fall off 
【294】on their own or be removed during your followup visit.
【295】
【296】Call your doctor for:
【297】* fever > 100.4F
【298】* severe abdominal pain
【299】* difficulty urinating
【300】* vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr
【301】* abnormal vaginal discharge
【302】* redness or drainage from incision
【303】* nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food 
【304】or your medication
【305】
【306】Constipation:
【307】* Drink ___ liters of water every day.
【308】* Incorporate 20 to 35 grams of fiber into your daily diet to 
【309】maintain normal bowel function. Examples of high fiber foods 
【310】include:
【311】Whole grain breads, Bran cereal, Prune juice, Fresh fruits and 
【312】vegetables, Dried fruits such as dried apricots and prunes, 
【313】Legumes, Nuts/seeds. 
【314】* Take Colace stool softener ___ times daily.
【315】* Use Dulcolax suppository daily as needed.
【316】* Take Miralax laxative powder daily as needed. 
【317】* Stop constipation medications if you are having loose stools 
【318】or diarrhea.
【319】To reach medical records to get the records from this 
【320】hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.
【321】 
【322】Followup Instructions:
【323】___

【102】received lovenox for DVT prophylaxis starting on the morning of 
【103】POD#1.  The foley was removed on POD#2 and the patient was 
【104】voiding independently thereafter. The surgical dressing was 
【105】changed on POD#2 and the surgical incision was found to be clean 
【106】and intact without erythema or abnormal drainage. The patient 
【107】was seen daily by physical therapy. Labs were checked throughout 
【108】the hospital course and repleted accordingly. At the time of 
【109】discharge the patient was tolerating a regular diet and feeling 
【110】well.  The patient was afebrile with stable vital signs.  The 
【111】patient's hematocrit was acceptable and pain was adequately 
【112】controlled on an oral regimen. The operative extremity was 
【113】neurovascularly intact and the wound was benign.

【168】Discharge Instructions:
【169】1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your 
【170】physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain 
【171】not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased 
【172】sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, 
【173】shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision 
【174】site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns.
【175】
【176】2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this 
【177】admission and any new medications and refills.  
【178】 
【179】3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed.
【180】 
【181】4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do 
【182】not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while 
【183】taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer 
【184】tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can 
【185】cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily 
【186】and take a stool softener (such as colace) as needed to prevent 
【187】this side effect.  Call your surgeons office 3 days before you 
【188】are out of medication so that it can be refilled.  These 
【189】medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be 
【190】picked up in the clinic or mailed to your house.  Please allow 
【191】an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your 
【192】home.
【193】
【194】5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your 
【195】surgeon.
【196】
【197】6. Please keep your wounds clean. You may shower starting five 
【198】(5) days after surgery, but no tub baths or swimming for at 
【199】least four (4) weeks. No dressing is needed if wound continues 
【200】to be non-draining. Any stitches or staples that need to be 
【201】removed will be taken out by the visiting nurse (___) or rehab 
【202】facility two 
【203】weeks after your surgery.
【204】
【205】7. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your 
【206】follow-up appointment in four (4) weeks.
【207】
【208】8. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal anti-inflammatory 
【209】medications (NSAIDs such as celebrex, ibuprofen, advil, aleve, 
【210】motrin, etc). You may continue your aspirin 81mg daily.
【211】
【212】9. ANTICOAGULATION: Please continue your lovenox for four (4) 
【213】weeks to help prevent deep vein thrombosis (blood clots).  You 
【214】may continue your Aspirin 81mg daily.  ___ STOCKINGS x 6 WEEKS.
【215】
【216】10. WOUND CARE: Please keep your incision clean and dry. It is 
【217】okay to shower five days after surgery but no tub baths, 
【218】swimming, or submerging your incision until after your four (4) 
【219】week checkup. Please place a dry sterile dressing on the wound 
【220】each day if there is drainage, otherwise leave it open to air. 
【221】Check wound regularly for signs of infection such as redness or 
【222】thick yellow drainage. Staples will be removed by the visiting 
【223】nurse or rehab facility in two (2) weeks.
【224】
【225】11. ___ (once at home): Home ___, dressing changes as 
【226】instructed, wound checks, and staple removal at two weeks after 
【227】surgery.
【228】
【229】12. ACTIVITY: Weight bearing as tolerated on the operative 
【230】extremity. Posterior precautions. No strenuous exercise or heavy 
【231】lifting until follow up appointment.

【240】with abdominal ultrasound recommended). She was noted to have 
【241】anemia during preoperative work up and was transfused 2 units of

【243】treated with Ciprofloxacin. She remained hemodynamically stable

【245】operating room on ___ and underwent aortic valve 
【246】replacement and coronary artery bypass grafting x 3. Please see

【262】telemetry floor for further recovery.  The patient was

【290】admission, and a brief episode of

【292】outside hospital prior to admission were negative for acute 
【293】pathology. He was quite aware of the confusion, commenting on 
【294】his own deficits in his memory including difficulty with 
【295】remembering his wife's birthday. He was oriented x2, unable to 
【296】remember the year. Initial concern for possible encephalitis. LP 
【297】was performed but returned frank blood, likely from epidural 
【298】vessel. Patient reported vision disturbances and was found to 
【299】have right homonymous hemianopsia. Repeat MRI/MRA of the brain 
【300】revealed acute ischemic PCA infarct. Patient was started on ASA 
【301】81mg and high-intensity atorvastatin. TTE did not show evidence 
【302】of PFO. Patient did not exhibit any atrial fibrillation on 
【303】telemetry, but was discharged with continuous monitoring for 
【304】further evaluation.

【102】Brief Hospital Course:
【103】Mr ___ was admitted to the transplant surgery service on 
【104】___ after undergoing a left hepatic lobectomy. He tolerated 
【105】the procedure well and was extubated in the OR prior to 
【106】recovering in the PACU prior to being transferred to the 
【107】surgical floor. For full details please see the dictated 
【108】operative report. Post-op he was kept NPO with IV fluids. His 
【109】pain was controlled with an epidural catheter and a foley was 
【110】left in place. He received ancef and flagyl for a total of 3 
【111】doses perioperatively. On POD 1 he was started on sips. He was 
【112】tachycardic to the 120's with otherwise normal vital signs. His 
【113】rhythm was sinus and he was unresponsive to fluid bolus, though 
【114】he continued to make large amounts of urine. His Hct was stable 
【115】at 37.5. The following day he continued to be tachycardic and 
【116】was febrile to 102.9, urine culture and chest x-ray were 
【117】negative, however blood cultures were positive for enterococcus. 
【118】He was initially started on unasyn however he was switched to 
【119】vanc/cipro/flagyl for broad spectrum coverage shortly thereafter 
【120】until his blood cultures speciated several days later. He was 
【121】given a clear liquid diet which he tolerated without issue. On 
【122】POD 3 he remained afebrile with sinus tachycardia. His epidural 
【123】was removed, he was started on PO pain medications, his foley 
【124】catheter was removed, he voided without difficulty and he was 
【125】started on a regular diet. The following day his antibiotics 
【126】were switched to unasyn/cipro as his enterococcus was found to 
【127】be sensitive to ampicillin. On ___ he was febrile to 101.4. 
【128】Fever workup was un revealing. The following day he continued to 
【129】complain of abdominal pain and a CT of the abdomen and pelvis 
【130】found a collection in gallbladder fossa as well as a pelvic 
【131】collection. On ___ an ___ intra-abdominal drain was placed 
【132】with 20cc purulent fluid which eventually speciated mixed 
【133】bacteria. His oxycodone was increased which resulted on improved 
【134】pain control. On ___ his WBC increased to 19.9 so blood 
【135】cultures were sent and a CXR was obtained and found to be un 
【136】revealing. He was noted to have phlebitis over his left forearm 
【137】at the site of a prior IV site to which a warm compress was 
【138】applied.  
【139】Blood cultures through ___ have all been no growth following 
【140】the initial positive blood culture on ___. There is 
【141】additionally one set of blood cultures from ___ which are no 
【142】growth to date but not yet finalized.
【143】The drainage from the ___ placed pigtail drain has diminished to 
【144】___ cc daily, and that drain was discontinued prior to 
【145】discharge.
【146】WBC has been dropping daily. He was switched to Ampicillin IV 
【147】for discharge to home, and a PICC line was placed in the left 
【148】arm.
【149】Total biliruin was 1.5 on admission, and has trended down to 0.3 
【150】on day of discharge. Patient was provided with a lamivudine 
【151】script. AST and ALT have trended down, alk phos has risen to 151

【197】Brief Hospital Course:
【198】This is a ___ year old male with a history of HIV on HAART (CD4 
【199】of 728 in ___, poorly controlled type 1 diabetes on Insulin, 
【200】recently diagnosed Hepatitis C, and multiple previous skin 
【201】infections who presented with hyperglycemia and lower abdominal 
【202】pain with negative abdominal CT scan. 
【203】.
【204】ACTIVE ISSUES BY PROBLEM:
【205】#Diabetes Mellitus, Type 1: Patient presented to primary doctor 
【206】with hyperglycemia to 697.  On admission, he did no have 
【207】evidence of full diabetic ketoacidosis--he had a normal anion 
【208】gap and hypokalemia.  He did show evidence of osmotic diuresis 
【209】and subsequent dehydration.  He was treated with IV fluids, 
【210】insulin per his home sliding scale with additional 6 units of 
【211】humalog and 33 units of glargine.
【212】     High blood sugars were likely precipitated by poor 
【213】adherence, as conceded by the patient. Patient agreed to 
【214】consider Insulin pump to improve adherence. Likelihood of 
【215】ischemic event is low with normal Troponin and EKG without 
【216】changes from prior.  Infectious precipitant also unlikely 
【217】without fever, clear CXR, and no leukocytosis.  His urine tox 
【218】screen was negative for cocaine as a possible inciting event. 
【219】The patient should follow up with ___ re: Insulin pump 
【220】(Omnipod brand) since he is repeatedly non-compliant with his 
【221】home sliding scale requiring multiple admissions and manifesting 
【222】in ongoing kidney failure and barrier to hepatitis C treatment.
【223】.
【224】#Abdominal pain: Patient describeed low-grade sensation similar 
【225】to hunger ache. Abdominal pain often occurs in the context of 
【226】hyperglycemia because high blood sugars and low insulin lead to 
【227】poor gastric emptying and ileus.  Additionally, patient had a 
【228】lot of stool on abd CT and has been constipated per history.  
【229】Possibility of pancreatitis was discounted with abd CT despite 
【230】mildly elevated lipase.  He was discharged on ranitidine and 
【231】multivitamins.
【232】.
【233】#Alkalosis: On admission, he was hypochloremic and with a 
【234】bicarbonate of 34.  However, he was saline responsive, dropping 
【235】from 34 to 30 with 4L of NS. Thus, alkalosis was likely a 
【236】"contraction alkalosis" secondary to profound dehydration. 
【237】.
【238】# Acute kidney injury (___): Likely secondary to dehydration 
【239】from high blood sugars (see above). Patient has underlying 
【240】chronic kidney disease (CKD) with a baseline Cr of 1.5 presumed 
【241】to be from diabetic nephropathy.  Patient should be on an ACE 
【242】inhibitor given CKD and proteinuria.  He Cr improved to baseline 
【243】by the time of discharge.     
【244】.
【245】CHRONIC ISSUES BY PROBLEM:
【246】#Abnormal liver function tests (LFTs): Upon admission, his 
【247】AST/ALT were elevated from ___.  It was felt that this was 
【248】due to his untreated hepatitis C.   Treatment is being postponed 
【249】in light of poorly controlled Diabetes, per note in OMR.  No 
【250】evidence of hepatomegaly on physical exam or on Abd. CT.  No 
【251】evidence of ascites on exam which would concern for SBP as cause 
【252】of his abd pain.
【253】.
【254】#HIV: Undetectable viral load on ___. CD4 count 728 on 
【255】admission. Patient reports good compliance with medications. No 
【256】history of opportunistic infections.   Frequent skin infections 
【257】are more likely due to poorly controlled DM than HIV. 
【258】He was continued on Sustiva and Truvada. 
【259】.
【260】#Hyperlipidemia: Previous ___ measured on ___. 
【261】Patient has normal total Cholesterol but high triglycerides, 
【262】possibly secondary to HIV medications. Consider starting 
【263】Fibrates on outpatient basis.
【264】.
【265】# Anemia: Patient was discharged with hemoglobin of 13.5, he 
【266】presented with hemoglobin of 16 which trended down after 4+ 
【267】liters of fluids.  This is likely a dilutional effect and the 
【268】patient does not report any bleeding or dark stools.
【269】.
【270】TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
【271】- Please consider alternative glucose regimens for this patient 
【272】because he has been consistently non-compliant with his current 
【273】regimen resulting in multiple hospital admissions for 
【274】hyperglycemia and manifesting as CKD
【275】- Please consider initiation of an ACE inhibitor for renal 
【276】protection given his CKD and proteinuria.
【277】- Please consider starting a fibrate for hypertriglyceridemia

【117】Brief Hospital Course:
【118】Ms. ___ was admitted on ___ under the acute care surgery
