【175】 
【176】Discharge Condition:
【177】Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
【178】Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
【179】Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
【180】 
【181】Discharge Instructions:
【182】Dear Ms. ___,
【183】
【184】You were admitted to ___ and 
【185】were found to have acute cholecystitis. You underwent a 
【186】laparoscopic cholecystectomy (gall bladder removal). You are 
【187】recovering well and are now ready for discharge. Please follow 
【188】the instructions below to continue your recovery:
【189】
【190】You will be discharged on one more day of antibiotic therapy. 
【191】Please finish all medication as prescribed. 
【192】
【193】You had an MRI scan done as part of the assessment of your acute 
【194】cholecystitis. You had a 1.4cm lesion incidentally discovered on 
【195】your right kidney. You will need a repeat renal (kidney) MRI to 
【196】further assess this lesion. Please follow up with your primary 
【197】care doctor to arrange this. 
【198】
【199】You were admitted to the hospital with acute cholecystitis. You 
【200】were taken to the operating room and had your gallbladder 
【201】removed laparoscopically. You tolerated the procedure well and 
【202】are now being discharged home to continue your recovery with the 
【203】following instructions.
【204】 
【205】Please follow up in the Acute Care Surgery clinic; you may call 
【206】___ to schedule an appointment in approximately 2 
【207】weeks.
【208】 
【209】ACTIVITY:
【210】 
【211】o Do not drive until you have stopped taking pain medicine and 
【212】feel you could respond in an emergency.
【213】o You may climb stairs. 
【214】o  You may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until 
【215】you see your surgeon at your next visit.
【216】o  Don't lift more than ___ lbs for 4 weeks. (This is about 
【217】the weight of a briefcase or a bag of groceries.) This applies 
【218】to lifting children, but they may sit on your lap.
【219】o You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable.
【220】o You will need to stay out of bathtubs or swimming pools for a 
【221】time while your incision is healing. Ask your doctor when you 
【222】can resume tub baths or swimming.
【223】 
【224】HOW YOU MAY FEEL: 
【225】o  You may feel weak or "washed out" for a couple of weeks. You 
【226】might want to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you.
【227】o  You may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in your 
【228】throat during surgery.
【229】o  You might have trouble concentrating or difficulty sleeping. 
【230】You might feel somewhat depressed.
【231】o  You could have a poor appetite for a while. Food may seem 
【232】unappealing.
【233】o  All of these feelings and reactions are normal and should go 
【234】away in a short time.  If they do not, tell your surgeon.
【235】 
【236】YOUR INCISION:
【237】o Tomorrow you may shower and remove the gauzes over your 
【238】incisions. Under these dressing you have small plastic bandages 
【239】called steri-strips. Do not remove steri-strips for 2 weeks. 
【240】(These are the thin paper strips that might be on your 
【241】incision.) But if they fall off before that that's okay).
【242】o Your incisions may be slightly red around the stitches. This 
【243】is normal.
【244】o You may gently wash away dried material around your incision.
【245】o Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area.
【246】o Do not use any ointments on the incision unless you were told 
【247】otherwise.
【248】o You may see a small amount of clear or light red fluid 
【249】staining your dressing or clothes. If the staining is severe, 
【250】please call your surgeon.
【251】o You may shower. As noted above, ask your doctor when you may 
【252】resume tub baths or swimming.
【253】 
【254】YOUR BOWELS:
【255】o Constipation is a common side effect of narcotic pain 
【256】medications. If needed, you may take a stool softener (such as 
【257】Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such as milk of 
【258】magnesia, 1 tbs) twice a day. You can get both of these 
【259】medicines without a prescription.
【260】o If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain 
【261】moving the bowels, call your surgeon. 
【262】 
【263】PAIN MANAGEMENT:
【264】o It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain following abdominal 
【265】surgery. This pain is often described as "soreness". 
【266】o Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain 
【267】is getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon.
【268】o You will receive a prescription for pain medicine to take by 
【269】mouth. It is important to take this medicine as directed. o Do 
【270】not take it more frequently than prescribed. Do not take more 
【271】medicine at one time than prescribed.
【272】o Your pain medicine will work better if you take it before your 
【273】pain gets too severe.
【274】o Talk with your surgeon about how long you will need to take 
【275】prescription pain medicine. Please don't take any other pain 
【276】medicine, including non-prescription pain medicine, unless your 
【277】surgeon has said its okay.
【278】o If you are experiencing no pain, it is okay to skip a dose of 
【279】pain medicine.
【280】o Remember to use your "cough pillow" for splinting when you 
【281】cough or when you are doing your deep breathing exercises.
【282】If you experience any of the following, please contact your 
【283】surgeon:
【284】- sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several hours
【285】- pain that is getting worse over time
【286】- pain accompanied by fever of more than 101
【287】- a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain
【288】 
【289】MEDICATIONS:
【290】Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just as 
【291】you did before, unless you have been told differently.
【292】If you have any questions about what medicine to take or not to 
【293】take, please call your surgeon.
【294】
【295】JP Drain Care:
【296】*Please look at the site every day for signs of infection 
【297】(increased redness or pain, swelling, odor, yellow or bloody 
【298】discharge, warm to touch, fever).
【299】*Maintain suction of the bulb.
【300】*Note color, consistency, and amount of fluid in the drain. Call 
【301】the doctor, ___, or ___ nurse if the amount 
【302】increases significantly or changes in character.
【303】*Be sure to empty the drain frequently. Record the output, if 
【304】instructed to do so.
【305】*You may shower; wash the area gently with warm, soapy water.
【306】*Keep the insertion site clean and dry otherwise.
【307】*Avoid swimming, baths, hot tubs; do not submerge yourself in 
【308】water.
【309】*Make sure to keep the drain attached securely to your body to 
【310】prevent pulling or dislocation.
【311】

【314】___

【258】injury, likely AIN. ___ w diff showed 10.1% eosinophilia (abs

【260】recent CAUTI. No muddy brown casts and no eos were seen on

【263】hemodialysis, and that the benefit of prednisone to treat AIN 
【264】would be outweighed by the side effects of decreased wound 
【265】healing and increased risk of infection. All nephrotoxic 
【266】medications/agents were avoided. All other medications were 
【267】dosed renally. Antibiotics were held as it was the likely 
【268】precipitant of the AIN.

【273】for CAUTI with ceftazidime. Most recent UCx on ___ revealed 
【274】proteus and e coli sensitive to ceftaz, ceftriaxone, zosyn,

【276】the past year. Has chronic indwelling foley at baseline which 
【277】was exchanged in the ED. UA with WBC >182, many bacteria, +leuks 
【278】with an uptrending leukocytosis and AMS (per son). Given concern 
【279】for UTI she did receive 1 dose of CTX in the ED. However, UA 
【280】pyuria could be better explained by AIN iso ceftaz use, and 
【281】bacteria colonization could be a chronic issue, and UCx showed 
【282】yeast. Repeat UA after Foley exchange w few bacteria. After the 
【283】1 dose of CTX, all antibiotics were held given suspicion for 
【284】AIN.

【288】inability to excrete free H2O in renal failure. Serum osmo 305, 
【289】likely elevated given BUN also elevated in setting ___ and is 
【290】likely actually hypoosmolar. We also obtained Urine Osm 272, UNa 
【291】27, possibly hypovolemic hyponatremia in setting of decreased 
【292】effective arterial blood volume, but hard to interpret given 
【293】worsening renal function. Na at 127 and trended up to 133 at 
【294】time of discharge before transition to CMO.

【298】Lactate wnl, no ketones and glucose in 150s with a near 
【299】compensated pH on VBG, low concern for DKA. Delta/delta 
【300】indicates coexisting high anion gap and normal anion gap 
【301】acidosis. Thus, we avoided NS to not worsen the acidosis, with 
【302】preference for LR. Likely due to renal failure. Per renal recs, 
【303】we gave bicarbonate replacement 2tabs TID to help compensation. 
【304】Electrolytes were trended daily until goals of care directed no 
【305】further laboratory testing.

【307】#Troponinemia: 
【308】EKG in the ED with no concerning ST changes, new q waves, or 
【309】twi. Troponin 0.24 in ED which is around her baseline on her 
【310】last admission. CKMB elevated 12, remained stable x2 in the ED. 
【311】Likely demand ischemia in setting of new urinary tract 
【312】infection. Serial troponins trending upwards to 0.31. Repeated 
【313】ACS workup as cannot assess for symptoms otherwise. Repeat ECGs 
【314】showed no ischemic change. Likely d/t decreasing renal fx, 
【315】unable to clear troponin from her blood and hence we did not 
【316】continue to trend to plateau. No heparin gtt and no aspirin load 
【317】was started. 
【318】
【319】#Craniocervical jx soft tissue density: 
【320】CT head neck ordered in ED; incompletely characterized soft 
【321】tissue density at the craniocervical junction w extension 
【322】inferiorly and laterally with erosion of the R lateral mass of 
【323】C1 and dens. Could be degenerative per radiology but given rapid 
【324】progression compared to prior imaging, MRI recommended. Known hx 
【325】of CNS lymphoma. Primary onc looped into discussion, verified 
【326】pt's poor prognosis, that potential for sufficient recovery for 
【327】another cycle of chemo is vanishingly low. Non urgent MRI 
【328】recommended by radiology, but decided against this admission 
【329】given transition in goals of care to CMO.

【455】INVESTIGATION OF TRANSFUSION REACTION (___)
【456】DIAGNOSIS, ASSESSMENT AND RECOMMENDATIONS: Ms. ___ 
【457】experienced
【458】rigors, bone pain, a rash about 1.5 hours after infusion of an
【459】apheresis-derived allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell therapy 
【460】product.
【461】There was also agitation, however, by report, the patient was 
【462】confused
【463】prior to the stem cell infusions. Hemolysis is unlikely given an 
【464】ABO
【465】compatible apheresis stem cell product. Bacterial cultures of 
【466】the stem
【467】cell product showed no growth.
【468】 
【469】The patient's rigors may represent a response to cytokines, 
【470】similar to a
【471】febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHTR), due to 
【472】infusion of
【473】white blood cells.
【474】 
【475】The rash, however, is not consistent with an FNHTR and was 
【476】reported as
【477】morbilloform and not urticarial, as would be expected if there 
【478】was an
【479】allergic reaction. In addition, it was almost two hours from 
【480】infusion
【481】until symptoms occurred and the patient has had fevers in the 
【482】previous
【483】days and a positive blood culture. As such, other non-infusion 
【484】related
【485】causes of fever should be considered.
【486】 
【487】In summary, an FNHTR may have been contributed to the patient's
【488】symptoms. The patient is restricted to leukoreduced red cell and
【489】platelet products and this modification signficantly reduces the 
【490】risk of
【491】FNHTRs (a stem cell product, however, cannot be leukoreduced due 
【492】to loss
【493】of stem cells).

【496】Brief Hospital Course:
【497】___ is a ___ year old female with high risk AML 
【498】s/p re-induction with MEC induction and decitabine consolidation 
【499】with evidence of CR on ___ BMbx. She presented for MUD 
【500】allogenic BM transplant on ___ (Day 0). During the course 
【501】of her hospital stay, the following issues were addressed:
【502】
【503】# AML. Relapsed AML s/p re-induction with MEC chemotherapy. By 
【504】BMBx in CR2, FISH negative for trisomy 8. BMBx pre-transplant on 
【505】___ showed CR. Her conditioning was unfortunately truncated 
【506】in the setting of sepsis as below and decreased functional 
【507】status. She received a total of 120 of fludarabine, ___ doses of 
【508】busulfan, and 1 ATG infusion before conditioning stopped. She 
【509】reached nadir on ___, Day 9 and showed evidence of count 
【510】recovery starting around Day ___, with platelet increase from 
【511】33-43. She was placed on acyclovir prophylaxis for the entirety 
【512】of her hospital stay, micafungin from ___, before switch 
【513】to fluconazole 400 mg daily on ___. Cyclosporine levels with 
【514】some fluctuations to supratherapeutic levels but largely 
【515】therapeutic. On ___ switched to oral cyclosporine. Discharged 
【516】with plan for pentamidine inhalation as an outpatient for PCP 
【517】___.
【518】
【519】# Sepsis and febrile neutropenia:  Became Febrile ___ at end of 
【520】ATG infusion. Defervesced then spiked again to 103 on the 
【521】morning of ___, with corresponding sepsis physiology, 
【522】tachypnea, AMS and elevated lactate to 5.5. MAPs stayed stable. 
【523】She was transferred to the FICU, received aggressive fluid 
【524】resuscitation with 4 L IVF and started on vancomycin, aztreonam 
【525】and IV cipro. This was deemed most likely due to subclavian line 
【526】infection. Ms. ___ had exquisite pain at site, with a 
【527】hematoma that likely served as nidus for infection. Her line was 
【528】pulled and her condition seemed to improved. Lactate peaked at 
【529】5.8 and decreased with IVF. She was in the ICU for 24 hrs with 
【530】subsequent resolution of tachypnea and encephalopathy and 
【531】transfer back to ___ service on ___. A single blood cltx grew 
【532】back VRE. She was switched from vanco to daptomycin on ___,

【537】6), albumin 3.1, INR 1.4. Was thought by hepatology to be most

【541】worsening sepsis so these two entities were likely not

【547】rate control regimen of carvedilol 6.25 mg PO BID, Diltiazem XR 
【548】120 mg Daily and on apixaban 5 mg PO BID. After episode of

【551】subsequently brought under good control. She was discharged on

【553】well as a reduced dose of apixaban while on fluconazole, 
【554】apixaban 2.5 mg BID.
【555】
【556】# Transfusion Reaction: On ___ Ms. ___ experienced a 
【557】severe reaction after infusion of apheresis-derived allogeneic 
【558】hematopoietic stem cells. 2 hours after second infusion bag was 
【559】finished, she experienced rigors, hip and jaw pain, flushing, 
【560】and a morbiliform rash over her back. Subsequent product 
【561】cultures showed no growth. After blood back investigation, 
【562】deemed that patient's rigors may represent a response to 
【563】cytokines, similar to a
【564】febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHTR), due to 
【565】infusion of white blood cells. 
【566】No changes to future transfusions/infusions were recommended.
【567】

【569】#DM: Managed well with metformin and insulin sliding scale at 
【570】home. Placed on sliding scale and fixed dose insulin in-house 
【571】with good effect.

【574】and Triamcinolone Acetonide 0.025% Cream 1 BID PRN:itch. Held 
【575】lasix in setting of sepsis and then continued to discharge.

【51】pressor requirement, these were discontinued. Her pressor 
【52】requirement increased during her hospital stay. She received

【54】Pulmonary: Upon her arrival in the ED, her O2 sat briefly 
【55】dropped to the ___ but came back up. She required a

【61】upon arrival, but she did receive albumin intermittently to

【5】 
【6】Service: NEUROSURGERY
【7】

【9】nuts / coconuts / oxycodone
【10】 
【11】Attending: ___.
【12】 
【13】Chief Complaint:
【14】aneurysm 
【15】 
【16】Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
【17】___ Right Craniotomy for Aneurysm Clipping, Dr. ___ 
【18】
【19】 
【20】___ of Present Illness:
【21】the ___.  As you may recall, the patient is a
【22】___ right-handed female with a history of headache,
【23】ongoing since mid ___.  Evaluation revealed a 3-mm 
【24】anterior
【25】communicating artery aneurysm, which was seen on ___.  
【26】She
【27】was then seen in the emergency room recently for what appeared 
【28】to
【29】be a syncopal episode.  She has had a persistent headache since
【30】___, and then, she developed an episode of syncope feeling
【31】warm, diaphoretic and tremulous.  She had normal dinner 
【32】including
【33】a glass of wine and then smoked marijuana to help her headache
【34】before sitting down in a recliner to watch television, and she
【35】did not feel like she had a fall subsequently.  This happened in
【36】the bathroom, and it does not appear to have been a seizure, but
【37】when she woke up, her head was in the bathtub and her mother 
【38】came
【39】and brought her to the emergency room.  A CT scan was done, 
【40】which
【41】did not show any evidence of subarachnoid hemorrhage.  Her past
【42】medical history is otherwise significant for headache, neck 
【43】pain,
【44】dysmenorrhea and allergic rhinitis. Patient underwent an 
【45】angiogram for further characterization of the aneurysm. She 
【46】presents today for elective craniotomy for clipping of aneurysm 
【47】. 
【48】
【49】 
【50】Past Medical History:
【51】None 
【52】 
【53】Social History:
【54】___
【55】Family History:
【56】Significant for father with diabetes and
【57】___ dementia.  Mother is healthy.  Brother has cerebral
【58】aneurysm status post rupture.
【59】
【60】 
【61】Physical Exam:
【62】Upon discharge: 
【63】Patient is alert and oriented x 4. PEARL 2 brisk. Speech is 
【64】clear and appropriate. Follows commands, ___ strengths in all 
【65】extremities. Face is symmetric, tongue midline, no pronator 
【66】drift. Sensory intact. 
【67】Right craniotomy incision is clean/dry/intact with sutures; no 
【68】drainage/redness noted. 
【69】 
【70】Pertinent Results:
【71】___ CT head 
【72】1. Aneurysm clip streak artifact limits examination. 
【73】2. Status post right frontotemporal craniotomy for aneurysm 
【74】clipping with 
【75】expected postoperative changes, including bifrontal 
【76】pneumocephalus. 
【77】
【78】 
【79】Brief Hospital Course:
【80】Ms. ___ was admitted for elective surgery. She underwent a 
【81】right craniotomy for clipping of ACA aneurysm. The procedure was 
【82】successful and well tolerated. She was extubated in the OR. She 
【83】underwent post operative NCHCT which revealed expected post 
【84】surgical changes. She complained and nausea post operatively. 
【85】She was started on a triple anti-emetic regimen for control of 
【86】nausea. 
【87】
【88】ON ___ Nausea was improved. Her foley and arterial line were 
【89】discontinued. She was transferred to the floor. 
【90】
【91】On ___, patient remains neurologically intact and 
【92】hemodynamically stable. Patient states her nausea and headache 
【93】have improved. She has been voiding and taking adequate PO. 
【94】Patient ambulated with nursing staff and cleared for discharge 
【95】to home with assistance from family and friends.
【96】 
【97】Medications on Admission:
【98】fioricet, Topamax, cyclobenzaprine, Tylenol 
【99】
【100】 
【101】Discharge Medications:
【102】1. Acetaminophen 325-650 mg PO Q6H:PRN fever or pain 
【103】2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
【104】3. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 
【105】RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ capsule(s) by mouth every 6 hours as 
【106】needed Disp #*60 Capsule Refills:*0
【107】4. Senna 17.2 mg PO QHS 
【108】5. Topiramate (Topamax) 25 mg PO BID 
【109】
【110】 
【111】Discharge Disposition:
【112】Home
【113】 
【114】Discharge Diagnosis:
【115】Right Anterior Communicating Artery Aneurysm 
【116】
【117】 
【118】Discharge Condition:
【119】Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
【120】Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
【121】Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
【122】
【123】 
【124】Discharge Instructions:
【125】Call your neurosurgeons office and speak to the Nurse 
【126】Practitioner if you experience:
【127】
【128】-Any neurological issues, such as change in vision, speech or 
【129】movement
【130】
【131】-Swelling, drainage, or redness of your incision
【132】
【133】-Any problems with medications, such as nausea vomiting or 
【134】lethargy
【135】
【136】-Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit
【137】
【138】-Headaches not relieved with prescribed medications
【139】
【140】Activity:
【141】
【142】-Start to resume all activities as you tolerate  but start 
【143】slowly and increase at your own pace.
【144】
【145】-Do not operate any motorized vehicle for at least 10 days after 
【146】your surgery  your Nurse Practitioner can give you more detail 
【147】at the time of your suture removal.  
【148】
【149】Incision Care:
【150】
【151】-Keep your wound clean and dry.
【152】
【153】-Do not use shampoo until your sutures are removed. 
【154】
【155】-When you are allowed to shampoo your hair, let the shampoo run 
【156】off the incision line.  Gently pad the incision with a towel to 
【157】dry.
【158】
【159】-Do not rub, scrub, scratch, or pick at any scabs on the 
【160】incision line.
【161】
【162】-You need your sutures removed 7 to 10 days after surgery
【163】
【164】Post-Operative Experiences: Physical
【165】
【166】-Jaw pain on the same side as your surgery; this goes away after 
【167】about a month
【168】
【169】-You may experience constipation.  Constipation can be prevented 
【170】by:
【171】
【172】oDrinking plenty of fluids
【173】oIncreasing fiber in your diet by eating vegetables, prunes, 
【174】fiber rich breads and cereals, or fiber supplements
【175】oExercising
【176】oUsing over-the-counter bowel stimulants or laxatives as needed, 
【177】stopping usage if you experience loose bowel movements or 
【178】diarrhea
【179】
【180】-Fatigue which will slowly resolve over time
【181】
【182】-Numbness or tingling in the area of the incision; this can take 
【183】weeks or months to fully resolve
【184】
【185】-Muffled hearing in the ear near the incision area
【186】
【187】-Low back pain or shooting pain down the leg which can resolve 
【188】with increased activity
【189】
【190】Post-Operative Experiences: Emotional
【191】
【192】-You may experience depression.  Symptoms of depression can 
【193】include
【194】
【195】oFeeling down or sad
【196】oIrritability, frustration, and confusion
【197】oDistractibility
【198】oLower Self-Esteem/Relationship Challenges
【199】oInsomnia
【200】oLoneliness
【201】
【202】-If you experience these symptoms, you can contact your Primary 
【203】Care Provider who can make a referral to a Psychologist or 
【204】Psychiatrist
【205】
【206】-You can also seek out a local Brain Aneurysm Support Group in 
【207】your area through the Brain Aneurysm Foundation
【208】
【209】oMore information can be found at ___
【210】
【211】 
【212】Followup Instructions:
【213】___

【27】The patient reports she had her first migraine ___ years ago 
【28】after
【29】the birth of her second son. Her typical migraine is always L
【30】sided (never R sided) and associated with a visual aura of
【31】"squiggly lines" and "difficulty with depth perception" which
【32】improves when she covers one eye (?diplopia). HAs are throbbing,
【33】with nausea, vomiting, and photophobia. She was started on
【34】verapamil as a prophylactic medication which was effective: her
【35】migraine frequency decreased to once every ___ months. When she
【36】got a headache she took hydrocodone which was effective in
【37】aborting the headache. She previously tried triptans which gave
【38】her nausea. She still intermittently required ED visits to
【39】"break" a bad migraine. She states she had an MRI of her brain a
【40】long time ago which was reportedly normal.
【41】
【42】On ___ the patient was at her ___ house in ___ and was woken up from sleep at 6 AM by what she describes
【43】as her typical migraine headache. No preceding illnesses or head
【44】injuries. She started vomiting later that morning and went to a
【45】local ED, which give her Compazine and another medication IV.
【46】This temporarily resolved her HA, and she went home, but later
【47】that day had recurrence of her headache and went back to a
【48】different ED where she got tramadol and a nausea medication.
【49】Again the next 2 days she continues to have migraine headches.
【50】Her PCP then prescribed her a 20 day prednisone taper, which
【51】improved her headache so that she could function better, but she
【52】continued to have now a daily headache. She is now off the
【53】prednisone and continues to have daily headache. She feels her
【54】daily functioning is impaired. She reports difficulty with
【55】concentration and recently ordered 11 garlic breads by mistake
【56】from Peapod, and paid her bills to the wrong amount (last months
【57】amount instead of this months). She was also started on Depakote
【58】for her headaches, and since then feels that her balance is a
【59】little off and she is stumbling more, and also notes a postural
【60】tremor which impairs her handwriting. She is also taking Fiorcet
【61】TID, indomethacin TID, tramadol TID, but has not noted a big
【62】improvement with any of them. Out of everything, the very first
【63】dose of steroids seemed to help the most, but she continued to
【64】have headaches daily during the long 20 day taper.
【65】
【66】She describes her current headache as L sided, throbbing,
【67】associated with L ear tinnitus and photophobia. No nausea or
【68】vomiting.
【69】
【70】She did get a NCHCT as part of her work up which was reportedly

【72】system.

【75】in for admission to Neurology to "break" her headache as well as
【76】exclude underlying brain lesion or temporal arteritis as causes
【77】of secondary headache. She received IV Mg, Compazine, and
【78】dilaudid in the ED.

【81】confusion. Denies jaw claudication, PMR symptoms.

【83】Denies loss of vision, blurred vision, diplopia, vertigo,
【84】tinnitus, hearing difficulty, dysarthria, or dysphagia.
【85】Denies muscle weakness.
【86】Denies loss of sensation.
【87】Denies bowel or bladder incontinence or retention.
【88】Endorses difficulty with gait.
【89】
【90】On general review of systems, the patient denies fevers, rigors,
【91】night sweats, or noticeable weight loss.
【92】Denies chest pain, palpitations, dyspnea, or cough.
【93】Denies nausea, vomiting, diarrhea.

【99】- multinodular goiter

【101】- s/p surgery for rotator cuff tear

【103】- s/p RT thumb surgery

【227】Ms. ___ is a ___ yo female admitted to Neurology Service for 
【228】status migranosus x7 weeks in setting of multiple medications.

【233】hours. Nortryptyline was considered, but it would interact with 
【234】her paxil. Topamax was started and titrated up to 50mg BID. She 
【235】had significant neck muscle spasm and so was also given 
【236】tizanidine which did seem to improve headache somewhat. Pain was 
【237】consulted and performed several nerve blocks after which her 
【238】headache was much improved. She was then discharged home with 
【239】follow up with pain medicine and with neurology.

【294】Dear Ms. ___, 
【295】
【296】You were admitted for headache. We stopped your fiorecet, 
【297】indomethacin, Depakote and Percocet for concern of worsening

【299】increased and you were started on Topamax and a muscle relaxer

【303】You should keep well hydrated, and try to get as much sleep as 
【304】possible. We switched your sleeping pill to Benadryl as there is 
【305】a small chance that trazodone can cause migraines. Try to 
【306】minimize the medications that you take for breakthrough headache 
【307】to avoid rebound headache.

【30】that time she had ___ "medium" brown loose stools without any

【34】and cereal with milk for breakfast. Shortly thereafter, she 
【35】developed crampy abdominal pain and attempted to move her 
【36】bowels. At that time she reports she passed only bright red 
【37】blood. She continued to have about 8 similar episodes were she 
【38】passed bright red blood with clots. She had a previously 
【39】scheduled appointment with her primary care physician ___ 3 ___, 
【40】and had a friend bring her to that. She has had no additional 
【41】episodes since that time. She reports that she noted that her 
【42】abdomen is more distended today, and she had some mild nausea 
【43】earlier in the day. No emesis or urinary symptoms. No fevers or 
【44】chills.

【150】emperic coverage, ? infectious colitis.  On the morning of first

【156】diarrhea and BRBPR, flexible sigmoidoscopy was done, which

【183】Brief Hospital Course:
【184】Mrs ___ was admitted on ___ with report of stumbling to 
【185】the left. It is unclear whether she was ataxic or had left leg 
【186】weakness. Her brain MRI showed no acute stroke. There were 
【187】chronic bilateral cerebellar infarcts and a right occipital 
【188】infarct. GRE showed two small areas in the right hemisphere 
【189】concerning for chronic hemorrhage. MRA neck and brain showed no 
【190】significant stensoses or dissection.  Her symptoms resolved 
【191】rapidly. Therefore her diagnosis was a transient ischemic 
【192】attack. This TIA may have occurred in the left cerebellum or the 
【193】right ACA territory. Etiology could be small vessel disease. 
【194】Although she had one episode of atrial flutter in the past, 
【195】there was no cardiac arrhythmia noted during this 
【196】hospitalization. Persantine stress test in ___ showed an EF 
【197】of 49%. A cardioembolic event seems unlikely. The fact that she 
【198】was not taking aspirin for several days prior to the event may 
【199】have contributed to the TIA. We restarted her on aspirin 81 mg 
【200】daily, and the renal team approved of this, as currently no 
【201】intervention is required for her AV fistula. She will have a TTE 
【202】as an outpatient.

【205】otherwise uneventful hospital stay.

【206】Take Aspirin 325mg (enteric coated) once daily 
【207】Take Plavix (Clopidogrel) 75mg once daily for one month
【208】Continue all other medications you were taking before surgery, 
【209】unless otherwise directed
【210】You make take Tylenol or prescribed pain medications for any 
【211】post procedure pain or discomfort
【212】
【213】WHAT TO EXPECT:
【214】It is normal to have slight swelling of the legs:
【215】Elevate your leg above the level of your heart with pillows 
【216】every ___ hours throughout the day and night
【217】Avoid prolonged periods of standing or sitting without your 
【218】legs elevated
【219】It is normal to feel tired and have a decreased appetite, your 
【220】appetite will return with time 
【221】Drink plenty of fluids and eat small frequent meals
【222】It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber, 
【223】lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to 
【224】maintain your strength and assist in wound healing
【225】To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool 
【226】softener while taking pain medication
【227】
【228】ACTIVITIES:
【229】When you go home, you may walk and use stairs
【230】You may shower (let the soapy water run over groin incision, 
【231】rinse and pat dry)
【232】Your incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small 
【233】amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing or 
【234】band aid over the area 
【235】No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 lbs) for 
【236】1 week (to allow groin puncture to heal)
【237】After 1 week, you may resume sexual activity
【238】After 1 week, gradually increase your activities and distance 
【239】walked as you can tolerate
【240】No driving until you are no longer taking pain medications

【244】Temperature greater than 101.5F for 24 hours
【245】New or increased drainage from incision or white, yellow or 
【246】green drainage from incisions
【247】Bleeding from groin puncture site
【248】
【249】SUDDEN, SEVERE BLEEDING OR SWELLING (Groin puncture site)
【250】Lie down, keep leg straight and have someone apply firm 
【251】pressure to area for 10 minutes. If bleeding stops, call 
【252】vascular office ___. If bleeding does not stop, call 
【253】___ for transfer to closest Emergency Room.

【190】the few days prior to presentation, patient has excellent 
【191】exercise tolerance of approximately 30 minutes of rigorous 
【192】exercise on elliptical machine daily. Had clopidogrel loading 
【193】dose in ED with dose of 600 mg. Patient  was without chest pain 
【194】prior to morning of ___ when he went for exercise nuclear 
【195】stress testing. Had been NPO overnight in anticipation of stress 
【196】MIBI, which was abnormal in that patient had hypotensive 
【197】response to exercise as well as having marked EKG changes.

【199】drip and eptifibatide prior to cardiac cath on afternoon of 
【200】___. Cardiac catheterization revealed an LAD lesion 
【201】consistent with in-stent restenosis. No other evidence of 
【202】coronary artery disease was found. A drug-eluting stent was 
【203】placed in the LAD stentosis. Patient did well 
【204】post-catheterization and was discharged without note of any 
【205】complications for the catheterization. At start of 
【206】hospitalization, initiated patient on aspirin 325 mg daily as 
【207】well as plavix 75 mg daily. These medications should be 
【208】continued for at least 12 months. We continued patient's home 
【209】regimen of ezetimibe/simvastatin ___. Patient had telemetry 
【210】monitoring with no concerning findings.

【22】This is a ___ male with a history of Crohn's disease, 
【23】nephrolithiasis, narcotic and polysubstance abuse who presents 
【24】with abdominal pain for 2 days prior to admission.  He states he 
【25】was in his normal state of health when he began to experience 
【26】increased watery bowel movements (BM)on ___.  There 
【27】was a dramatic increase in his bowel movements from ___ BMs 
【28】daily to upwards of 20 BMs.  The patient began experiencing 
【29】dehydration and began to increase his water intake to fluid 
【30】replenish.  There was no blood or mucus staining of the BM.  It 
【31】was not worse at any particular time of the day, however, each 
【32】BM made the overall discomfort in his abdomen worse.  (Of note, 
【33】the ED note described his diarrhea as "liquidy with mucous".  He 
【34】did not endorse mucous in our interview.)  
【35】.
【36】At the time of the increase in BM, he began to notice a mild 
【37】diffuse discomfort in his abdomen without localization above his 
【38】baseline level of discomfort.  The pain was described as 
【39】"cramp-like".  It did not change in quality for 24 hours until 
【40】midnight, ___.  At that time, the pain became more "crampy".  
【41】The patient was unable to get to sleep.  At 230am, ___, the 
【42】patient had a BM of watery stool.  Thirty minutes later, the 
【43】patient experienced a severe exacerbation of the pain.  He 
【44】"could not stand up or move."  "It was like I was knocked to the 
【45】floor."  The pain localized to his left lower quadrant (LLQ) at 
【46】this time.  It became "sharp" and "pinching".  According to the 
【47】patient, the change in his symptoms were c/w previous Crohn's 
【48】flare.  (His last flare according to him was a couple of months 
【49】ago.  This is corroborated by OMR.)  It did not radiate.  In 
【50】addition, nothing made the pain better.  He could not sleep the 
【51】rest of the night.  His persistent BMs completely stopped after 
【52】the 230am episode.  In fact, he reports constipation since then 
【53】as a consistent symptom.  He endorsed feeling chills, fatigue, 
【54】weakness during this latest exacerbation, and vomiting 2x on 
【55】___ and ___.  He denies recent weight change, vision 
【56】change, headache, and cough.  He reduced his appetite to 
【57】eliminate BMs in the hopes of decreasing his abdominal pain.  He 
【58】denies flank pain.  He called the GI physician covering for his 
【59】regular GI physician, ___.  He was instructed to 
【60】go to the ED.  The patient reports that he increased his at-home 
【61】medication of prednisone to 30 mg since ___.
【62】.
【63】In the ED, initial vitals were 98.5, 62, 165/85, 16, 99%RA. He 
【64】was given Dilaudid IV x 3 in ER.  He had a CT abdomen/pelvis 
【65】which did not show any e/o obstruction but did show some 
【66】increase fat stranding. He was given IVFs, then admitted to 
【67】medicine for Crohn's flare.  GI was consulted in ED and the plan 
【68】was to see him after being admitted to medicine. Vitals prior to 
【69】transfer were 97.2-52-18-115/53-98% r/a.

【155】Brief Hospital Course:
【156】This is a ___ man with Crohn's disease who presents with 
【157】increasing abdominal pain and decreased oral intake for 2 days 
【158】prior to admission.
【159】.
【160】ABDOMINAL PAIN:  Patient was given IVFs and Dilaudid in the ED 
【161】and transferred to medicine.  A CT abdomen/pelvis was negative 
【162】for obstruction but showed increased fat stranding at 
【163】ileo-sigmoid anastamosis.  CRP was not markedly elevated at 2.0. 
【164】 Upon arrival on the floor, patient was made NPO and given IVF 
【165】and dilaudid.  A flex sigmoidoscopy performed by GI showed:  
【166】"ulceration with several deep serpiginous ulcerations, 
【167】granularity, friability, a cobblestone appearance and erythema 
【168】in the ileosigmoid anastomosis...several apthous ulcerations in 
【169】the ileum."  Biopsy speciems were sent and were pending at time 
【170】of discharge.  CMV was also sent and is pending.  Ova/parasite 
【171】and c.diff were both negative.  
【172】.
【173】Patient felt better with IVF, bowel rest, and pain control.  He 
【174】declined hydrocortisone enemas as they hadn't helped him in the 
【175】past.  Patient began advancing diet on second hospital day and 
【176】was discharged in stable condition.  He was given a prescription 
【177】for dilaudid, compazine, and a steroid taper starting at 40mg 
【178】for the first week and decreasing by 10 every week.  He was told 
【179】to advance his diet as tolerated.  His GI doctor's office will 
【180】call him on ___ to schedule an appointment.  Patient was 
【181】given the number for HCA to establish care with a new PCP.
【182】.
【183】LEFT FLANK PAIN:  Patient complained of left flank pain on 
【184】admission.  A diagnosis of nephrolithiasis was entertained but 
【185】two urine analyses were negative for blood.  Flank pain 
【186】eventually resolved on second hospital day.
【187】.
【188】ANXIETY: Patient perseverates on challenges of his medical care. 
【189】 Upon admission he verbalized thoughts of potentially hurting 
【190】the medical student caring for him.  He became upset after the 
【191】flex sigmoidoscopy when the nurse tried to administer a 
【192】hydrocortisone enemas.  As his diet was advanced, he began 
【193】receiving his home dose of seroquel po.  He was treated with 
【194】ativan as needed for anxiety.  Upon discharge his mood had 
【195】calmed down.  
【196】.
【197】Patient was given heparin subq for DVT prophylaxis and a PPI for 
【198】GI prophylaxis.  He was discharged home with GI follow-up.
【199】

【203】___ 40 mg BID
【204】Prednisone 5 mg daily- recently increased to 30 mg daily

【210】day).  
【211】2. Pantoprazole 40 mg Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) Sig: One 
【212】(1) Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO Q24H (every 24 hours).  
【213】3. Prednisone 10 mg Tablet Sig: AS DIRECTED Tablet PO once a 
【214】day: 4 tablets x 7 days; 3 tablets x 7 days; 2 tablets x 7 days; 
【215】1 tablets x 7 days; 
【216】0.5 tablets afterwards.
【217】Disp:*80 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
【218】4. Hydromorphone 2 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO every six 
【219】(6) hours as needed for Pain for 5 days.
【220】Disp:*25 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
【221】5. Compazine 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO every six (6) 
【222】hours as needed for 5 days: Please take as needed for nausea.
【223】Disp:*25 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

【235】Discharge Instructions:
【236】You were admitted to the hospital for abdominal pain.  Based on 
【237】your symptoms at CT scan, you likely had a flare of your Crohn's 
【238】disease.  You were started on IV steroids, and had a flexible 
【239】sigmoidoscopy to evaluate your colon.  GI recommended that you 
【240】start hydrocortisone enemas but you didn't think they helped you 
【241】in the past.  You also complained of flank pain.  You've had 
【242】kidney stones in the past, though your urine this time did not 
【243】have any blood.  Your CT scan didn't show any evidence of stones 
【244】blocking your ureters.  You were treated with IV pain 
【245】medications, then switched to oral pain medications.
【246】

【105】##. Left Upper Lobe obstruction: Pt was admitted for fevers and 
【106】cough, chest x-ray on admission showed post-obstructive 
【107】pneumonia that failed to improve on a course of Ceftriaxone, 
【108】Vancomycin and Clindamycin. Pt was then seen by interventional 
【109】pulmonary for possible stent placement to improve drainage for 
【110】his pneumonia. Upon flexible bronchoscopy pt was noted to have 
【111】tumour with the left main bronchus. Pt was then rescoped with 
【112】rigid bronchoscopy and cryotherapy which unfortunately showed 
【113】complete obliteration of the left upper lobe bronchus secondary 
【114】to his thoracic mass. Pt's thoracic mass most likely tumour 
【115】versus abscess formation, case was discussed with pt's 
【116】outpatient Oncologist; he will follow up as an outpatient and 
【117】will likely be referred to Thoracic surgery for possible mass 
【118】removal. Per ID recommendation pt was discharged on Levofloxacin 
【119】and Clindamycin to prevent bacterial spread of possible abscess 
【120】to the vascular system. 
【121】  
【122】##. Left lung atelectasis: Following Mr. ___ rigid bronch his 
【123】Chest X-ray was notable for complete atelectasis. Pt's clinical 
【124】pulmonary exam however showed adequate aeration and saturation. 
【125】Pt was discharged following a course of incentive spirometry, 
【126】PEP therapy and respiratory therapy. 
【127】  
【128】##. Anemia: Pt was noted to be anemic during hospitalization 
【129】requiring a 1unit of PRBC transfusion. Hemolysis labs for anemia 
【130】work up was negative, pt's anemia most likely due to his 
【131】chemotherapy. 
【132】  
【133】##. Latent TB: Pt reported a history of a positive TB test with 
【134】only a month of treatment. As pt will also be undergoing 
【135】chemotherapy treatment for latent TB was started, pt currently 
【136】on a 9 month course of Isoniazid and Pyridoxine. Pt will also be 
【137】followed up in ___ clinic.

【190】Discharge Instructions:
【191】You were admitted to the hospital for fevers and a mass in the 
【192】left upper part of your lung.  Whilst in the hospital you were 
【193】given antibiotics but you still continued to have fevers. You 
【194】had two bronchoscopies which showed that there was a mass that 
【195】was blocking the left upper lobe of your lung. The blockage may 
【196】be from an abscess or your tumour. You will be seen by Dr. ___ 
【197】___ Dr. ___ on ___ to see if a surgeon can remove the 
【198】mass which is likely the cause of your fevers. We checked your 
【199】blood multiple times which showed no bacteria in your blood 
【200】system. Your fevers are most likely from the mass, you have been 
【201】clinically stable with the fevers and we feel it is safe for you 
【202】to be discharged.
【203】
【204】We started you on two antibiotics in case the mass is an 
【205】abscess. The antibiotics will help stop any bacteria spreading 
【206】to your blood system.
【207】
【208】Whilst in the hospital we also found that you had a history of a 
【209】positive TB skin test, when we tested you we found that your TB 
【210】infection is latent (not active but asleep). We started you on a 
【211】medication called Isoniazid which you will need to take over the 
【212】next 9 months. Please nake sure you take the Pyridoxine for the 
【213】next 9 months whilst you take the Isoniazid. You will have to 
【214】see the Infectious Disease doctor in ___ month, we will call you 
【215】to tell you when the appointment is. 
【216】
【217】You have been started on 4 new medications:
【218】
【219】1) You have been givewn two antibiotics to stop any abscess you 
【220】might have spread into your blood. These medications are called 
【221】Levofloxacin 750mg once a day and Clindamycin 300mg three times 
【222】a day. You will be taking both of these medications until Dr. 
【223】___ Dr. ___ you can stop.
【224】
【225】2) You have also been started on an antibiotic called Isoniazid 
【226】for your history of a positive TB test. You will need to take 
【227】this medication for 9 months last dose of this medication will 
【228】be ___. Please take Pyridoxine 100mg once a day for the 
【229】next month when you are taking the Isoniazid. You will also get 
【230】your blood checked once a month to check your liver function 
【231】once a month when you are on this medication.
【232】
【233】3) You have also been started on a stomach pill called 
【234】Pantoprazole, please take 40mg once a day.
【235】
【236】Please make sure you go to all of your appointments, we will 
【237】call you to tell you when to see the Infectious Disease doctor.
【238】
【239】If you start having fevers greater than 102 degrees, have 
【240】difficulty breathing, coughing up blood, chest pain please 
【241】return to the Emergency or call your doctor.

【264】Discharge Instructions:
【265】Discharge Instructions
【266】
【267】Activity
【268】We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing, 
【269】or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment.
【270】You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your 
【271】activity at your own pace once you are symptom free at rest. 
【272】___ try to do too much all at once.
【273】No driving while taking any narcotic or sedating medication. 
【274】If you experienced a seizure while admitted, you are NOT 
【275】allowed to drive by law. 
【276】No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon. You 
【277】should avoid contact sports for 6 months. 
【278】
【279】Medications
【280】       Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication 
【281】(Aspirin, Ibuprofen, Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the 
【282】neurosurgeon. 
【283】You have been discharged on Keppra (Levetiracetam). This 
【284】medication helps to prevent seizures. Please continue this 
【285】medication as indicated on your discharge instruction. It is 
【286】important that you take this medication consistently and on 
【287】time. 
【288】You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if 
【289】you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.
【290】
【291】What You ___ Experience:
【292】You may have difficulty paying attention, concentrating, and 
【293】remembering new information.
【294】Emotional and/or behavioral difficulties are common. 
【295】Feeling more tired, restlessness, irritability, and mood 
【296】swings are also common.
【297】Constipation is common. Be sure to drink plenty of fluids and 
【298】eat a high-fiber diet. If you are taking narcotics (prescription 
【299】pain medications), try an over-the-counter stool softener.
【300】
【301】Headaches:
【302】Headache is one of the most common symptom after a brain 
【303】bleed. 
【304】Most headaches are not dangerous but you should call your 
【305】doctor if the headache gets worse, develop arm or leg weakness, 
【306】increased sleepiness, and/or have nausea or vomiting with a 
【307】headache. 
【308】Mild pain medications may be helpful with these headaches but 
【309】avoid taking pain medications on a daily basis unless prescribed 
【310】by your doctor. 
【311】There are other things that can be done to help with your 
【312】headaches: avoid caffeine, get enough sleep, daily exercise, 
【313】relaxation/ meditation, massage, acupuncture, heat or ice packs. 
【314】
【315】
【316】When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for:
【317】Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the incision 
【318】site. 
【319】Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit
【320】Nausea and/or vomiting
【321】Extreme sleepiness and not being able to stay awake
【322】Severe headaches not relieved by pain relievers
【323】Seizures
【324】Any new problems with your vision or ability to speak
【325】Weakness or changes in sensation in your face, arms, or leg
【326】
【327】Call ___ and go to the nearest Emergency Room if you experience 
【328】any of the following:
【329】Sudden numbness or weakness in the face, arm, or leg
【330】Sudden confusion or trouble speaking or understanding
【331】Sudden trouble walking, dizziness, or loss of balance or 
【332】coordination
【333】Sudden severe headaches with no known reason
【334】
【335】 
【336】Followup Instructions:
【337】___

【33】to the ED.

【170】   VIRAL CULTURE (Preliminary):    No Virus isolated so far. 
【171】
【172】CT-Angiogram:  1. No evidence for pulmonary embolism.  2. Large 
【173】simple pericardial effusion with flattening and elongation of 
【174】the right ventricle suggestive of tamponade. Would recommend 
【175】evaluation with clinical exam and/or cardiac echocardiogram.  3. 
【176】Small left simple pleural effusion. Bilateral basilar 
【177】atelectasis, left greater than right. 4. Mild pulmonary vascular 
【178】congestion suggestive of mild volume overload. 5. Left thyroid 
【179】nodule, stable. Can further evaluate with dedicated ultrasound 
【180】or biochemical markers on a non-emergent basis. 
【181】.
【182】ABDOMINAL ULTRASOUND:  1. No acute intra-abdominal pathology. 2. 
【183】Hyperechoic focus within the liver likely representing a 
【184】hemangioma. Can further evaluate with dedicated liver CT on a 
【185】non-emergent basis. 3. Hyperechoic focus in the left kidney, 
【186】likely an AML. 4. Small left pleural effusion, better visualized 
【187】on CT examination from same day. 
【188】.
【189】CHEST XRAY:  1. Interval enlargement of cardiac silhouette, 
【190】pericardial effusion versus cardiomegaly.  2. Small left pleural 
【191】effusion with left basilar atelectasis or early pneumonia. 
【192】.
【193】CARDIAC ECHO ___: The interatrial septum is aneurysmal. The 
【194】left ventricular cavity size is normal. Due to suboptimal 
【195】technical quality, a focal wall motion abnormality cannot be 
【196】fully excluded. Overall left ventricular systolic function is 
【197】normal (LVEF>55%). Right ventricular chamber size and free wall 
【198】motion are normal. Trivial mitral regurgitation is seen. There 
【199】is a moderate to large sized pericardial effusion. The effusion 
【200】appears circumferential. There is right ventricular diastolic 
【201】collapse/compression, consistent with impaired 
【202】fillling/tamponade physiology. 
【203】Compared with the prior study (images reviewed) of ___, 
【204】the pericardial effusion is now much large. 
【205】
【206】POST TAP ECHO ___: There is a very small pericardial effusion. 
【207】There are no echocardiographic signs of tamponade (RV not well 
【208】imaged). No right atrial diastolic collapse is seen. Compared 
【209】with the prior study (images reviewed) of ___, the 
【210】effusion is much smaller.
【211】 
【212】Brief Hospital Course:
【213】___ F with HTN, HL presenting with pleuritic shoulder pain, 
【214】presyncope, nausea, found to have a pericardial effusion with 
【215】tamponade.
【216】
【217】PERICARDIAL EFFUSION:  On presenation pt had fluid seen on CTA, 
【218】found to have an increased pulsus paradoxus, and tamponade 
【219】confirmed with echo. Pt was taken to cath for tap of pericardial 
【220】fluid and drain placement. Pt reported immediate eleviation of 
【221】symptoms with fluid drainage except persistent chest/shoulder 
【222】pain with deep inspiration. After repeat ECHO showed minimal 
【223】residual fluid and no sign of recollection or tamponade, and 
【224】drain produced minimal output, pt's drain was removed. Pt then 
【225】felt additional relief of pain. 
【226】
【227】Regarding the etiology of the effusion infectious or malignant 
【228】causes were most likely, as these are the most common sources of 
【229】pericardial effustion and she has no history of radiation, renal 
【230】failure or collagen vascular disease.  Her family history of 
【231】breast and ovarian cancer increase the concern for malignant 
【232】cause, however the acute onset and history of a few weeks of 
【233】fevers and elevated WBC would favor infectious etiology.  Workup 
【234】included viral, bacterial and fungal cultures, which were all no 
【235】growth to date at time of discharge. Also checked TSH, ___, HIV 
【236】and cytology which were all normal. Pt has unchanged pulmonary 
【237】nodules regarding which she will follow up with pulmonary, 
【238】thyroid nodules which will be biopsies on ___, and guaiac 
【239】positive school for which she will schedule outpt 
【240】followup/workup. 
【241】
【242】ATRIAL FIBRILLATION: 
【243】Pt presented in atrial fibrillation, not anticoagulated due to 
【244】pt's wishes. She was continued on Aspirin and was not 
【245】recommended anticoagulation given the bloody pericardial fluid. 
【246】Pt was tachycardic early in the admission with an episode of RVR 
【247】requiring increased dose of beta blockers. Pt was switched from 
【248】her home atenolol 25mg to Metoprolol 25mg PO BID to have a more 
【249】consistent rate control. 
【250】On the day prior to discharge, pt spontaneously reverted to 
【251】normal sinus rhythm and remained there at a rate of ___ 
【252】until discharge. 
【253】
【254】Pt is to follow up with Dr ___ anticoagulation 
【255】in the future after having a repeat echocardiogram to document 
【256】resolution. 
【257】
【258】It is possible that a slowly growing pericardial effusion or 
【259】pericardial irritation may have been the cause of the atrial 
【260】fibrillation. Also possible but much less likely, is that the 
【261】atrial fibrillation is related to a silent MI, and the 
【262】pericardial fluid represents a Dressler's syndrome. 
【263】
【264】HYPOXIA: 
【265】After pt's pericardial fluid was drained she still required 
【266】significant oxygen supplementation via nasal cannula, especially 
【267】with movement. A CXR showed a small left-sided pleural effusion, 
【268】and some atelectasis, consistent with the bronchial sounds heard 
【269】at the left base on exam. Situation was attributed to 
【270】atelectasis in the setting of stenting from pleuritic pain. Pt's 
【271】O2 improved with use of incentive spirometry over time and at 
【272】discharge she was satting mid to high ___ on room air. 
【273】
【274】ELEVATED LFTS: 
【275】LFTs on presentation were AST 145, ALT 151, Alk Phos 197 and 
【276】were attributed to congestion in teh setting of RV failure from 
【277】tamponade. LFTs trended down throughout the hospital stay. 
【278】
【279】HYPERTENSION: Pt was started on Metoprolol for afib rate control 
【280】and blood pressures were also well controlled on this regimen 
【281】thus lisinopril and HCTZ (which were initially held given 
【282】tamponade physiology) were not restarted. BP was well controlled 
【283】and at time of discharge pt's SBP was ranging 100s-120s. 
【284】
【285】DEPRESSION: Pt was continued on her outpt regimen of Paxil
【286】
【287】PROPHYLAXIS: Given the possibility of malignancy causing 
【288】hypercoagulability and general immobility, pt was on Heparin 
【289】5000U TID subcataneously for DVT prophylaxis. 
【290】
【291】

【294】only taking 25 mg/day following low blood pressures last week

【297】day

【299】PAROXETINE HCL [PAXIL] - 20 mg Tablet - 1 Tablet(s) by mouth 
【300】once a day
【301】PRAVASTATIN [PRAVACHOL] - 20 mg Tablet - 1 Tablet(s) by mouth 1 
【302】po qd
【303】ASPIRIN -  (OTC) - 325 mg Tablet - 1 Tablet(s) by mouth once a 
【304】day
【305】OMEPRAZOLE MAGNESIUM [PRILOSEC OTC] -  (OTC) - 20 mg Tablet, 
【306】Delayed Release (E.C.) - 1 Tablet(s) by mouth once a day
【307】 
【308】Discharge Medications:
【309】1. Aspirin 325 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  
【310】2. Metoprolol Tartrate 25 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID 
【311】(2 times a day).
【312】Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
【313】3. Paroxetine HCl 20 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
【314】(Daily).  
【315】4. Pravastatin 20 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
【316】(Daily).  
【317】5. Fluticasone 50 mcg/Actuation Spray, Suspension Sig: One (1) 
【318】Spray Nasal BID (2 times a day).  
【319】
【320】

【322】Home

【325】Pericardial effusion

【333】Discharge Instructions:
【334】You had a pericardial effusion that was tapped to remove the 
【335】fluid. A repeat cardiac ECHO did not show any reaccumulation of 
【336】fluid. The fluid showed no signs of cancer or infection. 
【337】You are also in atrial fibrillation, which converted back to 
【338】sinus rhythm. If you have any palpitations or symptoms that your 
【339】atrial fibrillation has returned, please call Dr. ___ 
【340】___. You have an appt with ___ month to discuss 
【341】the atrial fibrillation. You also have multiple follow-up appts 
【342】to listed below for assessment of your pulmonary and throid 
【343】nodules. At your follow-up appt with Dr. ___.
【344】
【345】Please stop the following medicines:
【346】1.Lisinopril and HCTZ
【347】
【348】Please start these new medicines:
【349】1. Metoprolol (this will replace your Lisinopril and HCTZ in 
【350】lowering your blood pressure and will also control your heart 
【351】rate in case you revert back to Atrial Fibrillation)
【352】
【353】Please call your doctor or return to the emergency room if you 
【354】have any further chest pain, nausea, palpitations, trouble 
【355】breathing, swelling or any unusual symptoms.

【136】Discharge Instructions:
【137】Sister ___, 
【138】
【139】It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___ 
【140】___.  You were admitted to the hospital after a 
【141】peripheral angiogram.  We did this procedure to treat a 
【142】narrowing in your bypass graft to prevent the graft from 
【143】failing.   To do the procedure, a small puncture was made in 
【144】your left groin artery.  The puncture site heals on its own: 
【145】there are no stitches to remove.   You tolerated the procedure 
【146】well and are now ready to be discharged from the hospital.   
【147】Please follow the recommendations below to ensure a speedy and 
【148】uneventful recovery.
【149】
【150】Discharge Instructions Peripheral Angiography
【151】Puncture Site Care:
【152】For one week:
【153】Do not take a tub bath, go swimming or use a Jacuzzi or hot 
【154】tub.
【155】Use only mild soap and water to gently clean the area around 
【156】the puncture site. 
【157】Gently pat the puncture site dry after showering. 
【158】Do not use powders, lotions, or ointments in the area of the 
【159】puncture site. 
【160】
【161】You may remove the bandage and shower the day after the 
【162】procedure.  You may leave the bandage off. 
【163】You may have a small bruise around the puncture site.  This is 
【164】normal and will go away one-two weeks. 
【165】
【166】Activity 
【167】For the first 48 hours: 
【168】Do not drive for 48 hours after the procedure
【169】For the first week:
【170】Do not lift, push , pull or carry anything heavier than 10 
【171】pounds
【172】Do not do any exercises or activity that causes you to hold 
【173】your breath or bear down with abdominal muscles.   Take care not 
【174】to put strain on your abdominal muscles when coughing, sneezing, 
【175】or moving your bowels.
【176】
【177】After one week:
【178】You may go back to all your regular activities. We suggest you 
【179】begin your exercise program at half of your usual routine for 
【180】the first few days.   You may then gradually work back to your 
【181】full routine.
【182】
【183】Medications:
【184】Before you leave the hospital, you will be given a list of all 
【185】the medicine you should take at home.  If a medication that you 
【186】normally take is not on the list or a medication that you do not 
【187】take is on the list please discuss it with the team!  
【188】
【189】 
【190】Followup Instructions:
【191】___

【247】legs and back which are limiting your function currently and you

【250】return to work.

【253】bedtime to help ease your muscle spasms and allow you to sleep.

【255】OPERATE HEAVY MACHINERY while taking this medication, until you 
【256】know how it affects you.

【259】clots that we knew you have (for which you are on warfarin), and 
【260】also raised a question of a new blood clot in the left leg. Dr. 
【261】___ (Hematology/Oncology specialist) was consulted. He 
【262】examined you and looked at your ultrasound results and does not 
【263】feel that your current anticoagulation regimen should be 
【264】changed. Stay on the warfarin as prescribed and adjusted by the 
【265】___ clinic. He requested some bloodwork to make sure 
【266】you do not have a predisposition to developing blood clots and 
【267】will discuss the results with you when you see him in follow up. 
【268】He would also like to have you repeat the ultrasound of your 
【269】legs before you see him, approximately 10 weeks from today. If 
【270】you have increased swelling or pain or any new symptoms please 
【271】see your primary care doctor before that time.

【354】disorientation and somnolence, he was initially started on

【133】Discharge Instructions:
【134】-Please also refer to the instructions provided to you by the 
【135】manufacturer of this prosthesis
【136】
【137】- -AT least ONE to TWO times daily, GENTLY PULL THE BULB "DOWN" 
【138】into the dependent scrotum (unless otherwise explicitly 
【139】advised.)
【140】
【141】-ALWAYS call to inform, review and discuss any medication 
【142】changes and your post-operative course with your primary care 
【143】doctor.
【144】
【145】-over the next several days you may experience some increased 
【146】swelling of your phallus (and scrotum) resembling a semi-rigid 
【147】phallus (semi-erect); this is "normal" from the prosthesis and 
【148】related surgery/edema. This may be accompanied by discoloration 
【149】(ecchymosis) involving the phallus and the scrotum; this too is 
【150】normal and will gradually resolve.
【151】
【152】-Please remove the surgical dressing over penis and/or under 
【153】scrotum on post-operative day two: no further wound care is 
【154】needed and you may leave the wound open to air. 
【155】
【156】-Please keep your phallus at midline, pointed toward your 
【157】umbilicus, taped in place with protective gauze/pads (if 
【158】necessary) for the next ___ days. Of course you may point it 
【159】downward for voiding.
【160】
【161】-Use a jock-supporter/strap or jockey-type briefs or tight, 
【162】tighty-whities to facilitate this; Subsequently you may 
【163】transition to loose fitting briefs or boxer-briefs for 
【164】support--they should be cotton and/or breathable.
【165】
【166】-Do NOT use prosthesis for 6 weeks and until explicitly advised 
【167】by your urologist
【168】
【169】-Complete a 7-day course of antibiotics as directed 
【170】
【171】-You may shower, but do NOT bathe, swim or otherwise immerse 
【172】your incision.
【173】
【174】-Do NOT lift anything heavier than a phone book and no sports, 
【175】vigorous physical activity (including sexual).
【176】
【177】-Tylenol should be your first line pain medication, a narcotic 
【178】pain medication has been prescribed for breakthough pain >4.   
【179】The maximum daily Tylenol/Acetaminophen dose is ___ grams FROM 
【180】ALL sources.
【181】
【182】-Do NOT drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics and do NOT 
【183】operate dangerous machinery. 
【184】
【185】For your safety, please do NOT DRIVE FOR ONE WEEK AFTER SURGERY 
【186】or unless otherwise advised. 
【187】
【188】-Colace has been prescribed to avoid post-surgical constipation 
【189】and constipation related to narcotic pain medication, 
【190】discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops. Colace is a 
【191】stool "softener"- it is NOT a laxative
【192】
【193】-Resume your home medications, EXCEPT HOLD NSAIDs (aspirin, and 
【194】ibuprofen containing products such as Advil & Motrin, Excedrin) 
【195】for ONE week or until you see your urologist in follow-up OR you 
【196】are explicitly advised to resume sooner by your PCP, ___ 
【197】or Cardiologist.

【96】total of three doses thymo 125 mg given. Tacro was started on 
【97】the evening of POD 1, with daily levels checked and dosage

【101】was transfused two units of RBCs and a renal ultrasound was 
【102】obtained. This showed patent transplant renal vasculature with 
【103】slightly elevated resistive indices with no hydronephrosis or 
【104】perinephric fluid collection.

【112】hospital stay was 1.1 or 1.2, and was 1.2 on day of discharge. 
【113】Urine output was between 1500 and ___ cc daily.
【114】

【116】there was a large discrepancy between the A line that was placed 
【117】on the right arm below the fistula, and the left arm pressures 
【118】that he had typically been using at HD. The difference was 40 - 
【119】60 mmHg different. However, the left arm seemed to be 
【120】artificially high, as when the neo was titrated to keep the 
【121】right arm A line above 110, the urine output would increase.
【122】Decision was ultimately made to use cuff pressures on the right 
【123】arm.
【124】
【125】The patient was having orthostasis, which he does have a 
【126】longstanding history with his DM. He would become lightheaded 
【127】and feel weak. 
【128】On POD 4 from the kidney transplant, the patient had been off 
【129】Neo for 24 hours, and Midodrine had been started. As such he was 
【130】transferred to the regular surgical floor.
【131】
【132】Patient continued to have issues with his blood pressure, widely 
【133】variable from low ___ to mid ___. However with standing he was 
【134】continuing to have symptoms of orthostasis and was also 
【135】symptomatic.
【136】
【137】The midodrine was increased to 15 mg TID and florinef was added. 
【138】This too was titrated to final dose of 0.3 mg daily. Sodium 
【139】bicarb was added to increase salt load, and patient has been 
【140】encouraged to drink three liters daily.
【141】
【142】Blood glucose control was initially a challenge with the 
【143】steroids. Patient is followed as an outpatient by ___, and 
【144】the also followed him while in house. He was ultimately started 
【145】on Humalog ___ to be given BID at home, and has short term 
【146】follow up with ___ as well.
【147】
【148】Patient continues to have some symptoms of lightheadedness. He 
【149】has a wheelchair at home. He will be sent home with home ___ in 
【150】addition to nursing.
【151】He has short term follow up later this week.

【222】Discharge Instructions:
【223】Home Health ___ and physical therapy ___ has been 
【224】arranged to follow you at home. You will receive a call to 
【225】schedule a home visit on ___
【226】
【227】Please call the transplant clinic at ___ for fever > 
【228】101, chills, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, inability 
【229】to tolerate food, fluids or medications, yellowing of skin or 
【230】eyes, increased abdominal pain, incisional redness, drainage or 
【231】bleeding, dizziness or weakness, decreased urine output or dark, 
【232】cloudy urine, swelling of abdomen or ankles, or any other 
【233】concerning symptoms.
【234】
【235】When getting out of bed to chair, or chair to standing, rise 
【236】slowly, and don't move away from the bed or chair until you are 
【237】sure you are steady. Use your wheelchair as necessary.
【238】
【239】Bring your pill box and list of current medications to every 
【240】clinic visit.
【241】
【242】You will have labwork drawn every ___ and ___ as 
【243】arranged by the transplant clinic, with results to the 
【244】transplant clinic (Fax ___ . CBC, Chem 10, AST, T 
【245】Bili, Trough Tacro level, Urinalysis.
【246】
【247】*** On the days you have your labs drawn, do not take your Tacro 
【248】until your labs are drawn. Bring your Tacro with you so you may 
【249】take your medication as soon as your labwork has been drawn.
【250】
【251】Follow your medication card, keep it updated with any dosage 
【252】changes, and always bring your card with you to any clinic or 
【253】hospital visits.
【254】
【255】You may shower. Allow the water to run over your incision and 
【256】pat area dry. No rubbing, no lotions or powder near the 
【257】incision. You may leave the incision open to the air. The 
【258】staples are removed approximately 3 weeks following your 
【259】transplant.
【260】
【261】No tub baths or swimming
【262】
【263】No driving if taking narcotic pain medications
【264】
【265】Avoid direct sun exposure. Wear protective clothing and a hat, 
【266】and always wear sunscreen with SPF 30 or higher when you go 
【267】outdoors.
【268】
【269】Drink enough fluids to keep your urine light in color. Your 
【270】appetite will return with time. Eat small frequent meals, and 
【271】you may supplement with things like carnation instant breakfast 
【272】or Ensure.
【273】
【274】Check your blood sugars and treat with new scheduled Humalog mix 
【275】twice a day. Keep your ___ appointment as scheduled for next 
【276】week.
【277】
【278】Check your blood pressure on the right forearm only
【279】Report consistently elevated or low values to the transplant 
【280】clinic
【281】
【282】Do not increase, decrease, stop or start medications without 
【283】consultation with the transplant clinic at ___. There 
【284】are significant drug interactions with anti-rejection 
【285】medications which must be considered in medication management 
【286】following transplant.
【287】
【288】Consult transplant binder, and there is always someone on call 
【289】at the transplant clinic with any questions that may arise

【164】#Hemolysis:

【166】and continues to be elevated, concurrent with ongoing drops in 
【167】hemoglobin. The T. Bili has increased in the setting of 
【168】decreased haptoglobin, fibrinogen: 98, DAT negative, consistent 
【169】drops in Hgb and elevated but stable LDH; suggesting an 
【170】hemolytic process. Smear significant for acanthocytes and spur 
【171】cells consistent with liver disease. Most likely, extravascular 
【172】hemolytic anemia ___ to ongoing liver disease. Infectious work 
【173】up throughout his hospital stays have been negative. He will 
【174】have close outpatient follow up with his local hepatologist for 
【175】H/H monitoring and pRBCs as needed.

【178】at ___ for hyponatremia in the setting of 
【179】volume overload ___ to 
【180】decompensated EtOH cirrhosis with refractory ascites. During the 
【181】current admission, the patient tolerated Lasix 40 and 
【182】spironolactone 100 well with stable sodium, creatinine and 
【183】potassium. His lower extremity edema is also improved at 
【184】discharge and he will be continued on 40 Lasix and 100 
【185】spironolactone. 
【186】

【188】hyponatremia, minimal ascites and lower extremity edema. Lower 
【189】extremity edema improved on standing doses of his home diuretics 
【190】(Lasix 40 and spironolactone 100). Ascites culture on Day 6, 1

【192】empiric Bactrim (day 1: ___ for a total course of 7 days

【196】varices however no EGD records at ___. Nadolol was withheld in

【198】diuresis. He will need another screening EGD and colonoscopy

【204】platelets during admission which remained stable.

【225】Discharge Instructions:
【226】Please call the transplant clinic at ___ for fever 
【227】(temperature of 101 or greater, chills, nausea, vomiting, 
【228】diarrhea, constipation, inability to tolerate food, fluids or 
【229】medications, increased abdominal pain, incisional redness, 
【230】drainage or bleeding, dizziness or weakness, decreased urine 
【231】output or dark, cloudy urine, swelling of abdomen or ankles, or 
【232】any other concerning symptoms.
【233】
【234】You will have labwork drawn twice weekly as arranged by the 
【235】transplant clinic at ___ floor, ___ 
【236】___, with results to the transplant clinic 
【237】(Fax ___ . (CBC, Chem 10, AST, T Bili, Trough Tacro 
【238】level, Urinalysis). 
【239】
【240】On the days you have your labs drawn, do not take your 
【241】Tacrolimus until your labs are drawn. Bring your Tacrolimus with 
【242】you so you may take your medication as soon as your labwork has 
【243】been drawn.
【244】
【245】Follow your medication card, keep it updated with any dosage 
【246】changes, and always bring your card with you to any clinic or 
【247】hospital visits.
【248】
【249】You may shower. Allow the water to run over your incision and 
【250】pat area dry. No rubbing, no lotions or powder near the 
【251】incision. You may leave the incision open to the air. The 
【252】staples are removed approximately 3 weeks following your 
【253】transplant.
【254】No tub baths or swimming
【255】
【256】No driving if taking narcotic pain medications
【257】
【258】Avoid direct sun exposure. Wear protective clothing and a hat, 
【259】and always wear sunscreen with SPF 30 or higher when you go 
【260】outdoors.
【261】
【262】Drink enough fluids to keep your urine light in color. Your 
【263】appetite will return with time. Eat small frequent meals, and 
【264】you may supplement with Glucerna nutritional supplement.
【265】 
【266】Check your blood sugars and blood pressure at home. Report 
【267】consistently elevated values to the transplant clinic
【268】
【269】Do not increase, decrease, stop or start medications without 
【270】consultation with the transplant clinic at ___. There 
【271】are significant drug interactions with anti-rejection 
【272】medications which must be considered in medication management 
【273】following transplant
【274】
【275】Consult transplant binder, and there is always someone on call 
【276】at the transplant clinic with any questions that may arise

【126】Discharge Instructions:
【127】___, MD
【128】___ Instructions
【129】After ___ & Ankle Surgery
【130】 
【131】Thank you for allowing me to assist in your care. It is a 
【132】privilege to be able to take care of you. Should you have any 
【133】questions about your ___ care feel free to call my 
【134】office at ___ during business hours and either myself 
【135】or ___, PA-C will address any questions or 
【136】concerns you may have. If this is an urgent matter at night or 
【137】on weekends please call ___ and ask the page operator 
【138】to page the covering ___ call orthopaedic physician. 
【139】
【140】Prescription refills or changes cannot be addressed after normal 
【141】business hours or on weekends.
【142】
【143】PAIN CONTROL:
【144】
【145】-You may or may not have had a nerve block depending on the type 
【146】of surgery. This will likely wear off later in the evening and 
【147】it is normal to have increased pain when the nerve block wears 
【148】off. Please take your prescribed pain medications as directed 
【149】with food prior to the nerve block wearing off. 
【150】-Stay ahead of the pain!
【151】-Narcotic pain medications can cause constipation. Please take a 
【152】stool softener while taking these and drink plenty of water.
【153】-Please plan ahead! If you are running out of your medication 
【154】prior to your follow-up appointment please call during business 
【155】hours with a ___ day notice. Prescription refills or changes 
【156】cannot be addressed after normal business hours or on weekends.
【157】
【158】NON-NARCOTIC PAIN CONTROL
【159】
【160】-Multi-modal pain control is critical. If you are able to take 
【161】Tylenol (acetaminophen) I would strongly encourage you to do so 
【162】according to the instructions on the bottle. Do not take more 
【163】than 4,000 mg of Tylenol in 24 hours.
【164】-NSAIDs (Advil, Motrin, Aleve, etc) are also excellent for pain 
【165】control post-operatively. Do not take if you have had a bone 
【166】fusion surgery, but for soft tissue procedures or most fracture 
【167】surgeries these medications are acceptable unless you are unable 
【168】to take for other medical reasons or unless we have specifically 
【169】instructed you against it.
【170】-Elevation with the operative site above the level of the heart 
【171】will decrease swelling and improve pain control
【172】-Ice or cold therapy may also be helpful. Do not keep ice or 
【173】cold directly on the skin and do not use for more than ___ 
【174】minutes to decrease risk of skin injury from the cold. Do NOT 
【175】use ice when the block is still in effect as you will not know 
【176】if you are injuring yourself. You may place the ice pack behind 
【177】your knee if you have a bulky dressing on your ___. 
【178】-Every little bit helps. The faster you can come off the 
【179】narcotic medication the better. Most of my patients do not need 
【180】narcotics after the first ___ visit!
【181】
【182】ACTIVITY:
【183】
【184】-You will likely have swelling after surgery. Please keep the 
【185】___ elevated on ___ pillows at all times possible. You can 
【186】apply a dry, covered, ice-bag on top of your dressing or behind 
【187】your knee for 20 minutes at a time as often as you like.
【188】-Unless instructed otherwise you should not put any weight down 
【189】on your operated extremity until you come back for your first 
【190】postoperative visit.
【191】
【192】CARE FOR YOUR DRESSING:
【193】
【194】-You should not remove your dressing. I will do so when I see 
【195】you for your first ___ visit.
【196】-It is not unusual to have a little bloody staining through your 
【197】dressing. However please call the office for any concerns.
【198】-Keep your dressing clean and dry. You will have to cover it 
【199】when you bath or shower. If it gets wet please call the office 
【200】immediately.
【201】
【202】PREVENTION OF BLOOD CLOTS:
【203】
【204】-You have been instructed to take medication in order to help 
【205】prevent blood clots after surgery. Please take an aspirin 325 mg 
【206】every day unless you have been specifically prescribed a 
【207】different medication by me. If there is some reason why you 
【208】cannot take aspirin please notify my office.
【209】
【210】DRIVING:
【211】
【212】-My recommendation is that you should not drive if you:
【213】(1)are still taking narcotic pain medications
【214】(2)have any type of immobilization on your right side
【215】(3)are unable to fully bear weight without pain on your right 
【216】side
【217】(the above also apply to the left side if you have a manual 
【218】transmission (stick shift)
【219】
【220】-There is no substitute for common sense and safety. If you do 
【221】not feel safe driving, do not do so.  Practice in an empty 
【222】parking lot prior to driving on the road.  
【223】-Driving is easy. Stopping in an emergency is hard
【224】
【225】WHEN TO CALL:
【226】
【227】-Please call the office if you have any questions or concerns 
【228】regarding your ___ care. We need to know if things 
【229】are not going well.
【230】-Please make sure you call the office or page the ___ call 
【231】orthopaedic physician immediately if you are having any of the 
【232】following problems:
【233】1.Fever greater than 101.4
【234】2.Increasing pain not controlled on pain medications
【235】3.Increasing bloody staining on the dressing
【236】4.Chest pain, difficulty breathing, nausea or vomiting
【237】5.Significant asymmetric leg swelling

【67】General:
【68】The patient presented to Emergency Department from OSH for 
【69】further management of multiple traumas sustained from a bike Vs 
【70】car accident. More specifically, he suffered a comminuted left 
【71】scapular fracture, L scalp and auricle laceration. He was 
【72】evaluated by ACS and orthopedic consult was called to bedside.  
【73】Upon evalauation of imaging, the scapular fracture was minimally 
【74】displaced we elected for non-operative management. Following 
【75】recommendations from ortho, he was made none weight bearing in 
【76】the LUE and sling for comfort.

【79】standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored.

【83】toilet, early ambulation and incentive spirometry were 
【84】encouraged throughout hospitalization.

【87】once our orthopedic consult elected for non-operative 
【88】management.  He tolerated a regular diet without difficulty.

【91】infection, of which there were none.

【94】of bleeding, of which there were none.

【96】ambulated in the unit.

【99】and hemodynamically stable.  The patient was tolerating a diet, 
【100】ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
【101】controlled.  The patient received discharge teaching and 
【102】follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and
