【137】Discharge Instructions:
【138】ACTIVITY:
【139】o You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable.
【140】o You will need to stay out of bathtubs or swimming pools for a 
【141】time while your head laceration is healing. Ask your doctor when 
【142】you can resume tub baths or swimming.
【143】 
【144】HOW YOU MAY FEEL: 
【145】o  You may feel weak or "washed out" for a couple of weeks. You 
【146】might want to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you.
【147】o  You might have trouble concentrating or difficulty sleeping. 
【148】You might feel somewhat depressed.
【149】o  You could have a poor appetite for a while. Food may seem 
【150】unappealing.
【151】o  All of these feelings and reactions are normal and should go 
【152】away in a short time.  If they do not, tell your surgeon.
【153】 
【154】o Your laceration may be slightly red around the stitches. This 
【155】is normal.
【156】o You may gently wash away dried material around your incision.
【157】o Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area.
【158】o Do not use any ointments on the incision unless you were told 
【159】otherwise.
【160】o You may see a small amount of clear or light red fluid 
【161】staining your dressing or clothes. 
【162】 
【163】 
【164】PAIN MANAGEMENT:
【165】o Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain 
【166】is getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon.
【167】o You will receive a prescription for pain medicine to take by 
【168】mouth. It is important to take this medicine as directed. o Do 
【169】not take it more frequently than prescribed. Do not take more 
【170】medicine at one time than prescribed.
【171】o Your pain medicine will work better if you take it before your 
【172】pain gets too severe.
【173】o Talk with your surgeon about how long you will need to take 
【174】prescription pain medicine. Please don't take any other pain 
【175】medicine, including non-prescription pain medicine, unless your 
【176】surgeon has said its okay.
【177】o If you are experiencing no pain, it is okay to skip a dose of 
【178】pain medicine.
【179】o Remember to use your "cough pillow" for splinting when you 
【180】cough or when you are doing your deep breathing exercises.
【181】If you experience any of the following, please contact your 
【182】surgeon:
【183】- sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several hours
【184】- pain that is getting worse over time
【185】- pain accompanied by fever of more than 101
【186】- a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain
【187】 
【188】MEDICATIONS:
【189】Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just as 
【190】you did before, unless you have been told differently.
【191】If you have any questions about what medicine to take or not to 
【192】take, please call your surgeon.

【107】This patient is a ___ year old male who presented to the 
【108】emergency room with abdominal pain. He was admitted to the Acute 
【109】Care Surgery service after CT Scan imaging revealed "Sigmoid 
【110】diverticulitis with a contained perforation in association with 
【111】an intramural abscess." The patient had a white blood cell count 
【112】of 15.5 on admission. The patient was initiated on Intravenous 
【113】fluids, Intravenous antibiotics and strict bowel rest. He was 
【114】kept NPO until his diet was advanced to clear liquids on HD 3, 
【115】which he tolerated well. His pain was well controlled with IV 
【116】pain medications, however after receiving IV Antibiotics, pain 
【117】did improve. On the day of discharge, the patient was able to 
【118】tolerate a regular diet without experiencing nausea or vomiting.

【120】pending. The patient was seen by gastroenterology prior to 
【121】discharge in light of his diverticulitis. They recommended he 
【122】followup as an outpatient with a colonoscopy. On HD 4, the 
【123】patient denied abdominal pain and was transitioned to oral 
【124】antibiotics. He was discharged home with instructions to finish

【314】Brief Hospital Course:
【315】___ year old female with a prior history of diffuse large B-cell 
【316】lymphoma in the mediastinum s/p R-CHOP and R-EPOCH chemotherapy 
【317】and radiation [completed ___ who has been in complete 
【318】remission since then, who presented with recurrent fevers which 
【319】continued even on appropriate therapy for a Pseudomonas PNA and 
【320】C.diff. 
【321】
【322】# Fever of unknown origin:  The patient presented with ongoing 
【323】fevers.  During her hospital course infection was a major 
【324】concern in the differential.  Her fevers were initially thought 
【325】to be due to a recurrent pseudomonal pneumonia, however she was 
【326】treated appropriately with ceftazadime throughout her hospital 
【327】course and continued to experience fevers.  She was found to be 
【328】C.diff positive and was initially treated with po flaygl, 
【329】however this was changed to po vancomycin due to fever despite 
【330】tid Flagyl treatment of her C.diff colitis.  A PPD was placed 
【331】and was negative and a quantaferon-gold test was sent, the 
【332】results were pending at time of discharge.  Cultures from the 
【333】T11 biopsy, bone marrow, and pleural fluid were all no growth.  
【334】She did continued to grow pseudomonas from her sputum, making it 
【335】likely that this was a contaminant.  
【336】
【337】She underwent a throacentesis on admission which showed so many 
【338】white blood cells due to her pneumonia so that cytology could 
【339】not be accurately performed to evaluate for abnormal cells.  An 
【340】MRI of her T11 vertebrae showed abnormal bone marrow edema 
【341】concerning for malignancy so a CT-guided biopsy of T11 was 
【342】preformed.  Pathology showed only connective tissue and cultures 
【343】have been no growth to date.  Due to her history of a bronchial 
【344】stent in her left lobe she underwent a bronchoscopy to evaluate 
【345】for evidence of infection of the stent which was within normal 
【346】limits.  A BAL was done which grew pseudomonas.  Given 
【347】persistent pleural effusion and cough she underwent a second 
【348】thoracentesis which showed improvement of the white count of the 
【349】pleural fluid and 11% other cells which were described as 
【350】immature immunoblasts.  Cytology showed atypical cells.  Due to 
【351】concern for malignancy as a source of her fevers a bone marrow 
【352】biopsy was preformed which did not reveal any evidence of 
【353】malignancy.
【354】
【355】Besides infectious disease and heme/onc consults, rheumatology 
【356】was also consulted as rheumatologic disease remained in the 
【357】differential for FUO, however they did not feel that further 
【358】rheum workup was indicated given lack of history to point 
【359】towards a specific disease.
【360】
【361】# Respiratory distress: Throughout her hospitalization she had 
【362】multiple episodes of respiratory worsening, then improvement.  
【363】Her respiratory distress was initially thought to be due to her 
【364】pseudomonal PNA.  She began improving, but after the 
【365】bronchoscopy she worsened and her CXR showed a new infiltrate in 
【366】her RUL. She was treated for a possible MRSA HCAP for a 7 day 
【367】course with vancomycin.  She was placed on standing nebs and 
【368】guafenesin.  She was encouraged to use incentive spirometry and 
【369】get OOB with her family and ___.  Due to continued shortness of 
【370】breath with exertion a TTE was preformed which showed no acute 
【371】change but mildly decreased systolic function.
【372】
【373】# Psudomonas pneumonia:  She was thought to have recurrent 
【374】pseudomonas pneumonia from incomplete treatment after her 
【375】previous admission for pnueumonia.  There was some concern for 
【376】empyema given persistence of a right pleural effusion and a 
【377】thoracentesis was done which had elevated counts of red and 
【378】white blood cells but no organisms, and the culture was 
【379】negative.  There was also concern for lymphoma recurrence, but 
【380】cytology of the pleural cells was negative for atypical cells 
【381】and a CT of the chest and abdomen did not reveal any new areas 
【382】of adenopathy.  She was followed by both the heme-onc and 
【383】infectious disease consult services and was ultimately completed 
【384】a three week course of ceftazadime.  She will need five more 
【385】days of PO vancomycin. 
【386】
【387】# Right pleuritic chest pain:  This was thought to be secondary 
【388】to pleurisy from her right pleural effusion, and it improved 
【389】gradually over the course of her hospital stay.  A chest CTA was 
【390】performed to rule out pulmonary embolism and was negative.  She 
【391】was managed with tylenol and oxycodone prn.
【392】
【393】# Left subclavian vein stenosis:  She was found to have 
【394】significant collateral venous circulation in chest incidentally 
【395】on a chest CT to rule out PE, and this was consistent with 
【396】chronic obstruction of the left subclavian vein.  It was unclear 
【397】whether the obstruction was due to subclavian stenosis from the 
【398】left chest port catheter or a chronic thrombosis, and left upper 
【399】extremity ultrasound was performed which was negative for clot.  
【400】An MRV of the extremity was considered for further evaluation of 
【401】the nature of the stenosis, as a chronic clot could not be ruled 
【402】out with the ultrasound study, but after discussion with 
【403】radiology, it was determined that no noninvasive test would be 
【404】able to differentiate between chronic sclerosis and clot.  
【405】Because the collateral circulation suggested a chronic process 
【406】and because there was no concern for PE, it was concluded that 
【407】the stenosis was likely secondary to the existence of a port 
【408】catheter in the vein.
【409】
【410】# NHL: She has a history of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma in the 
【411】mediastinum s/p R-CHOP and R-EPOCH chemotherapy and radiation 
【412】[completed ___ and also has a right bronchial stentin place.  
【413】She has been in complete remission.  The heme-onc service was

【141】Discharge Instructions:
【142】___-Trillat Procedure (Tibial Tubercle Osteotomy)
【143】___, M.D.
【144】Post-operative Protocol
【145】
【146】Wound Care:
【147】  Remove dressing in 2 days.
【148】  Keep steri-strips in place until they fall off or they are 
【149】removed at your first post-operative visit.
【150】  Showering after 4 days is fine; be sure to pat the incision 
【151】dry afterwards.
【152】  Do not scrub the area; just allow water/soap to wash over 
【153】you.
【154】  Do not bath or swim until approved by surgeon.
【155】  Continue to wear your TEDS stockings for one week after 
【156】surgery to help decrease the swelling.  You may remove for 
【157】showering, etc.
【158】
【159】Ice:
【160】  We recommend that you use the ice wrap/cryocuff on a 
【161】consistent basis for the first 2448 hours. This will help 
【162】reduce post-operative swelling. After that, use as necessary. 
【163】  If the cryocuff is not available or if you find this 
【164】uncomfortable, you can simply apply an ice pack to your knee 3  
【165】4 times per day until the swelling resolves.
【166】  Use a cloth between the ice and your skin.  DO NOT place ice 
【167】directly on skin as this may cause ___ bite.  Do not leave ice 
【168】wrap or cold therapy on for more than 20 minutes without 
【169】checking your skin.  
【170】
【171】Braces:
【172】  With an ___ Trillat Procedure, you will wear your ___ 
【173】Brace in the locked in 20 degrees flexion at all times for 4 
【174】weeks after surgery.  After 4 weeks, the knee brace can be 
【175】unlocked to allow full range of motion.  You need to wear the 
【176】brace for a total of 6 weeks.  You may get a prescription for a 
【177】different brace at your second post op visit.
【178】  If you have a question about your brace or you need help 
【179】adjusting it, please call NOPCO at ___.
【180】
【181】Crutches & Weight bearing status:   
【182】  Following an Elmslie-Trillat Procedure, you will be able to 
【183】bear weight as tolerated with crutches.  You can transition away 
【184】from the crutches as you feel safe and able to do so.
【185】
【186】Physical Therapy: 
【187】  Formal physical therapy will be ordered by your orthopedic 
【188】surgeon in the form of a written prescription at your first post 
【189】op visit. You will also receive a therapy protocol form.  
【190】Following an Elmslie-Trillat, you should start formal physical 
【191】therapy at 4 weeks following surgery.  The prescription and 
【192】protocol should be given to a physical therapist of your choice 
【193】so you can begin your program as directed under close 
【194】supervision of your surgeon.
【195】
【196】Pain Control:
【197】Narcotics
【198】  You have been prescribed a narcotic pain medication.   You 
【199】may call ___ for refills as needed.  Please review a 
【200】copy of our narcotics policy which is attached.
【201】  Use the medication only as prescribed. Take it with food.
【202】  Do not drive or use any type of heavy machinery, drink 
【203】alcohol, make any life-changing or legal decisions (i.e. sign a 
【204】will), or participate in activities that require a lot of 
【205】physical skill.
【206】  Take a stool softener, such as Colace, while taking the 
【207】narcotic medication, because narcotics may cause constipation.
【208】
【209】Non- Steroidal Anti-Inflammatory Medications:
【210】  Please avoid NSAIDs for the first 4 weeks after surgery.  
【211】This could slow down your bone healing and increase your risk of 
【212】bleeding.
【213】  You will be given a prescription for Lovenox (a blood 
【214】thinning medication to prevent blood clots that is injected into 
【215】the stomach daily) that you will need to take this for 4 weeks 
【216】following surgery.
【217】
【218】Driving:
【219】  In general, you can resume driving after regaining range of 
【220】motion (approx 6 weeks after surgery) and when you have full 
【221】control of your arms and legs and you are pain free.  Do not 
【222】drive if you are still taking narcotic pain medications.
【223】
【224】Return to Work:
【225】  You may return to work as soon as you are comfortable and 
【226】able to safely weight bear using crutches.  This typically 
【227】occurs 14 weeks post-op.  Return to work notes can be obtained 
【228】from your orthopedic surgeon at your first post-op appointment.
【229】
【230】Follow-up Appointment:
【231】  Your first post-operative appointment will be scheduled 2 
【232】weeks following your surgical procedure. At this appointment 
【233】your sutures will be removed if needed.  If you do not have a 
【234】post-operative appointment scheduled when you leave following 
【235】surgery, please call ___ to make the appointment.  Your 
【236】first post-operative appointment will be with a Physicians 
【237】Assistant (PA) or a Nurse Practitioner (___).
【238】
【239】****Signs & Symptoms to Immediately Report****
【240】  Call ___ and go to the nearest hospital if you are having 
【241】chest pain or trouble breathing.
【242】Call the office at: ___ to report any of the following:
【243】  Persistent fever (101 or greater)
【244】  Sudden increase in pain and swelling
【245】  Wound redness or drainage
【246】  Increased skin temperature around incision
【247】  Deep calf pain and swelling
【248】
【249】Physical Therapy:
【250】Brace for 4 wks.
【251】WBAT x 4 wks with brace locked at 20 degrees.
【252】Crutches as needed.  Discontinue as able.

【98】The patient was admitted to the Colorectal sugery service after 
【99】undergoing a laparoscopic converted to open sigmoidectomy on 
【100】___. The procedure was complicated by a 1.5L blood loss, 
【101】requiring ressucitation with 6 units pRBC, 2 units FFP, 1 bag 
【102】platelets, 5 liters of crystaloid. The patient was transferred 
【103】to the ICU intubated, requiring neo for hypotension. On POD 1 
【104】the patient was weaned off of neo, extubated. The patient was 
【105】transferred to the floor. Pain well controlled with IV pain 
【106】medication. On POD 2 the patient NGT was removed. The patient 
【107】then went into respiratory distress. A CXR was performed that 
【108】showed bilateral pleural effusions and lower lobe consolidation. 
【109】The patient was given 20mg IV lasix, start on VAP protocol 
【110】(vancomycin, zosyn). The patient respiratory status improved 
【111】after administration of lasix, diuresis. On POD 3 the patient 
【112】was started on sips which he tolerated well. The patient went 
【113】into A-fib with RVR which was controlled with IV metoprolol and 
【114】IV dilt. On POD 4 the patient was advance to clears liquids 
【115】which he tolerated well. He was started on nadolol, 
【116】spironolactone. Lasix was held for systolic blood pressue in the 
【117】___. Patient's vancomycin was increased for trough of 13.4. On 
【118】POD 5 the patient had multiple bowel movements, was started on a 
【119】regular diet that he tolerated well. Patient's foley was 
【120】removed. Patient voided without difficulty. On POD 6 the patient 
【121】was started on oral pain medication, home medications. Patient 
【122】completed 5 day course of VAP antibiotics (vanc/zosyn).
【123】

【125】assistance, tolerating a regular diet, voiding without 
【126】difficulty, pain controlled on oral pain medication.

【282】Dear Mr. ___,

【284】We saw you in the hospital to initiate hemodialysis for your 
【285】kidney disease. You were also more short of breath than 
【286】previously and required extra oxygen. Echocardiogram imaging of 
【287】your heart showed some enlargement of your heart, but normal

【289】it looked very similar to your previous one in ___.

【292】the ___, which helped remove a significant amount of the 
【293】excess fluid in your body. During these sessions, you received 
【294】numerous blood transfusions to help with your chronic anemia 
【295】that is caused by your renal disease. When your left arm swelled 
【296】up after the first hemodialysis session, we did several tests to 
【297】rule out a clot in the arm and to check how well your fistula 
【298】was working. You received a procedure called a fistulogram, 
【299】which showed that there was a narrowing of the veins, which was 
【300】then fixed. 
【301】

【303】leaving the hospital. As part of your work-up to receive 
【304】hemodialysis in the out-patient setting, we screened you for TB 
【305】and for hepatitis viruses and your results were negative. We 
【306】have also stopped some of your home medications.

【330】Discharge Instructions:
【331】Dear Mr. ___,
【332】
【333】You were admitted to the hospital because you had chest pain. 
【334】You were found to have had a heart attack. Your heart arteries 
【335】were examined (cardiac catheterization) which showed a blockage 
【336】of one of the arteries that was previously by-passed. This was 
【337】opened by placing a tube called a stent in the artery. You 
【338】improved considerably and were ready to leave the hospital.
【339】
【340】WHAT DO YOU NEED TO DO WHEN YOU LEAVE THE HOSPITAL?  
【341】-It is very important to take your heart medications, most 
【342】importantly aspirin and prasugrel (also known as Effient) every 
【343】day.  
【344】-These two medications keep the stents in the vessels of the 
【345】heart open and help reduce your risk of having a future heart 
【346】attack.  
【347】-If you stop these medications or miss ___ dose, you risk causing 
【348】a blood clot forming in your heart stents, and you may die from 
【349】a massive heart attack.  
【350】- Take all of your medications as prescribed (listed below)  
【351】- Follow up with your doctors as listed below  
【352】- Seek medical attention if you have new or concerning symptoms 
【353】or you develop chest pain, swelling in your legs, abdominal 
【354】distention, or shortness of breath at night.

【356】It was a pleasure participating in your care. We wish you the
